With that he call’d the tailor lown;
He was a wight of high renown,
And thou art but of low degree.
’Tis pride that pulls the country down,
Then take thy auld cloak about thee.”
Some wine ho!

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: ’Fore God, this is a more exquisite song than the other.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Will you hear’t again?

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: No; for I hold him to be unworthy of his place that does those things. Well, God’s above all; and there be souls must be sav’d, and there be souls must not be sav’d.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: It’s true, good lieutenant.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: For mine own part—no offense to the general, nor any man of quality—I hope to be sav’d.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: And so do I too, lieutenant.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: Ay; but by your leave, not before me; the lieutenant is to be sav’d before the ancient. Let’s have no more of this; let’s to our affairs.—God forgive us our sins!—Gentlemen, let’s look to our business. Do not think, gentlemen, I am drunk: this is my ancient, this is my right hand, and this is my left hand. I am not drunk now; I can stand well enough, and I speak well enough.

speech.speaker: ALL.
speech.line: Excellent well.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: Why, very well then; you must not think then that I am drunk.

speech.speaker: MON.
speech.line: To th’ platform, masters, come, let’s set the watch.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: You see this fellow that is gone before:
He’s a soldier fit to stand by Caesar
And give direction; and do but see his vice,
’Tis to his virtue a just equinox,
The one as long as th’ other. ’Tis pity of him.
I fear the trust Othello puts him in,
On some odd time of his infirmity,
Will shake this island.

speech.speaker: MON.
speech.line: But is he often thus?

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: ’Tis evermore the prologue to his sleep.
He’ll watch the horologe a double set
If drink rock not his cradle.

speech.speaker: MON.
speech.line: It were well
The general were put in mind of it.
Perhaps he sees it not, or his good nature
Prizes the virtue that appears in Cassio,
And looks not on his evils. Is not this true?

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: How now, Roderigo?
I pray you, after the lieutenant, go.

speech.speaker: MON.
speech.line: And ’tis great pity that the noble Moor
Should hazard such a place as his own second
With one of an ingraft infirmity;
It were an honest action to say
So to the Moor.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Not I, for this fair island.
I do love Cassio well; and would do much
To cure him of this evil.
“Help! Help!”
But hark, what noise?

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: ’Zounds, you rogue! You rascal!

speech.speaker: MON.
speech.line: What’s the matter, lieutenant?

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: A knave teach me my duty? I’ll beat the knave into a twiggen bottle.

speech.speaker: ROD.
speech.line: Beat me?

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: Dost thou prate, rogue?

speech.speaker: MON.
speech.line: Nay, good lieutenant; I pray you, sir, hold your hand.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: Let me go, sir, or I’ll knock you o’er the mazzard.

speech.speaker: MON.
speech.line: Come, come—you’re drunk.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: Drunk?

speech.speaker: IAGO
speech.line: Away, I say; go out and cry a mutiny.
Nay, good lieutenant—God’s will, gentlemen—
Help ho!—lieutenant—sir—Montano—sir—
Help, masters!—Here’s a goodly watch indeed!
Who’s that which rings the bell? Diablo, ho!
The town will rise. God’s will, lieutenant, hold!
You’ll be asham’d forever.

scene.stagedir: Enter Othello and Gentlemen with weapons.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: What is the matter here?

speech.speaker: MON.
speech.line: ’Zounds, I bleed still,
I am hurt to th’ death. He dies.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Hold, for your lives!

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Hold ho! Lieutenant—sir—Montano—gentlemen—
Have you forgot all place of sense and duty?
Hold! The general speaks to you; hold, for shame!

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Why, how now ho? From whence ariseth this?
Are we turn’d Turks, and to ourselves do that
Which heaven hath forbid the Ottomites?
For Christian shame, put by this barbarous brawl.
He that stirs next to carve for his own rage
Holds his soul light; he dies upon his motion.
Silence that dreadful bell, it frights the isle
From her propriety. What is the matter, masters?
Honest Iago, that looks dead with grieving,
Speak: who began this? On thy love, I charge thee!

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: I do not know. Friends all, but now, even now;
In quarter, and in terms like bride and groom
Devesting them for bed; and then, but now
(As if some planet had unwitted men),
Swords out, and tilting one at other’s breast,
In opposition bloody. I cannot speak
Any beginning to this peevish odds;
And would in action glorious I had lost
Those legs that brought me to a part of it.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: How comes it, Michael, you are thus forgot?

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: I pray you pardon me, I cannot speak.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Worthy Montano, you were wont to be civil;
The gravity and stillness of your youth
The world hath noted, and your name is great
In mouths of wisest censure. What’s the matter
That you unlace your reputation thus,
And spend your rich opinion for the name
Of a night-brawler? Give me answer to it.

speech.speaker: MON.
speech.line: Worthy Othello, I am hurt to danger.
Your officer, Iago, can inform you—
While I spare speech, which something now offends me—
Of all that I do know, nor know I aught
By me that’s said or done amiss this night,
Unless self-charity be sometimes a vice,
And to defend ourselves it be a sin
When violence assails us.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Now by heaven,
My blood begins my safer guides to rule,
And passion, having my best judgment collied,
Assays to lead the way. ’Zounds, if I stir,
Or do but lift this arm, the best of you
Shall sink in my rebuke. Give me to know
How this foul rout began; who set it on;
And he that is approv’d in this offense,
Though he had twinn’d with me, both at a birth,
Shall lose me. What, in a town of war,
Yet wild, the people’s hearts brimful of fear,
To manage private and domestic quarrel?
In night, and on the court and guard of safety?
’Tis monstrous. Iago, who began’t?

speech.speaker: MON.
speech.line: If partially affin’d, or leagu’d in office,
Thou dost deliver more or less than truth,
Thou art no soldier.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Touch me not so near;
I had rather have this tongue cut from my mouth
Than it should do offense to Michael Cassio;
Yet I persuade myself, to speak the truth
Shall nothing wrong him. Thus it is, general:
Montano and myself being in speech,
There comes a fellow crying out for help,
And Cassio following him with determin’d sword
To execute upon him. Sir, this gentleman
Steps in to Cassio and entreats his pause;
Myself the crying fellow did pursue,
Lest by his clamor (as it so fell out)
The town might fall in fright. He, swift of foot,
Outran my purpose; and I return’d the rather
For that I heard the clink and fall of swords,
And Cassio high in oath; which till tonight
I ne’er might say before. When I came back
(For this was brief), I found them close together
At blow and thrust, even as again they were
When you yourself did part them.
More of this matter cannot I report.
But men are men; the best sometimes forget.
Though Cassio did some little wrong to him,
As men in rage strike those that wish them best,
Yet surely Cassio, I believe, receiv’d
From him that fled some strange indignity
Which patience could not pass.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: I know, Iago,
Thy honesty and love doth mince this matter,
Making it light to Cassio. Cassio, I love thee,
But never more be officer of mine.
Look if my gentle love be not rais’d up!
I’ll make thee an example.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: What is the matter, dear?

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: All’s well now, sweeting;
Come away to bed.
Sir, for your hurts,
Myself will be your surgeon.—Lead him off.
Iago, look with care about the town,
And silence those whom this vild brawl distracted.
Come, Desdemona, ’tis the soldiers’ life
To have their balmy slumbers wak’d with strife.

scene.stagedir: Exit with Desdemona, Gentlemen, and Attendants.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: What, are you hurt, lieutenant?

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: Ay, past all surgery.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Marry, God forbid!

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: Reputation, reputation, reputation! O, I have lost my reputation! I have lost the immortal part of myself, and what remains is bestial. My reputation, Iago, my reputation!

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: As I am an honest man, I had thought you had receiv’d some bodily wound; there is more sense in that than in reputation. Reputation is an idle and most false imposition; oft got without merit, and lost without deserving. You have lost no reputation at all, unless you repute yourself such a loser. What, man, there are more ways to recover the general again. You are but now cast in his mood, a punishment more in policy than in malice, even so as one would beat his offenseless dog to affright an imperious lion. Sue to him again, and he’s yours.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: I will rather sue to be despis’d than to deceive so good a commander with so slight, so drunken, and so indiscreet an officer. Drunk? And speak parrot? And squabble? Swagger? Swear? And discourse fustian with one’s own shadow? O thou invisible spirit of wine, if thou hast no name to be known by, let us call thee devil!

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: What was he that you follow’d with your sword? What had he done to you?

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: I know not.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Is’t possible?

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: I remember a mass of things, but nothing distinctly; a quarrel, but nothing wherefore. O God, that men should put an enemy in their mouths to steal away their brains! That we should, with joy, pleasance, revel, and applause, transform ourselves into beasts!

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Why, but you are now well enough. How came you thus recover’d?

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: It hath pleas’d the devil drunkenness to give place to the devil wrath: one unperfectness shows me another, to make me frankly despise myself.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Come, you are too severe a moraler. As the time, the place, and the condition of this country stands, I could heartily wish this had not befall’n; but since it is as it is, mend it for your own good.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: I will ask him for my place again, he shall tell me I am a drunkard! Had I as many mouths as Hydra, such an answer would stop them all. To be now a sensible man, by and by a fool, and presently a beast! O strange! Every inordinate cup is unbless’d, and the ingredient is a devil.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Come, come; good wine is a good familiar creature, if it be well us’d; exclaim no more against it. And, good lieutenant, I think you think I love you.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: I have well approv’d it, sir. I drunk!

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: You, or any man living, may be drunk at a time, man. I’ll tell you what you shall do. Our general’s wife is now the general—I may say so in this respect, for that he hath devoted and given up himself to the contemplation, mark, and denotement of her parts and graces. Confess yourself freely to her; importune her help to put you in your place again. She is of so free, so kind, so apt, so bless’d a disposition, she holds it a vice in her goodness not to do more than she is requested. This broken joint between you and her husband entreat her to splinter; and my fortunes against any lay worth naming, this crack of your love shall grow stronger than it was before.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: You advise me well.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: I protest, in the sincerity of love and honest kindness.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: I think it freely; and betimes in the morning I will beseech the virtuous Desdemona to undertake for me. I am desperate of my fortunes if they check me here.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: You are in the right. Good night, lieutenant, I must to the watch.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: Good night, honest Iago.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: And what’s he then that says I play the villain,
When this advice is free I give, and honest,
Probal to thinking, and indeed the course
To win the Moor again? For ’tis most easy
Th’ inclining Desdemona to subdue
In any honest suit; she’s fram’d as fruitful
As the free elements. And then for her
To win the Moor, were’t to renounce his baptism,
All seals and symbols of redeemed sin,
His soul is so enfetter’d to her love,
That she may make, unmake, do what she list,
Even as her appetite shall play the god
With his weak function. How am I then a villain,
To counsel Cassio to this parallel course,
Directly to his good? Divinity of hell!
When devils will the blackest sins put on,
They do suggest at first with heavenly shows,
As I do now; for whiles this honest fool
Plies Desdemona to repair his fortune,
And she for him pleads strongly to the Moor,
I’ll pour this pestilence into his ear—
That she repeals him for her body’s lust,
And by how much she strives to do him good,
She shall undo her credit with the Moor.
So will I turn her virtue into pitch,
And out of her own goodness make the net
That shall enmesh them all.
How now, Roderigo?

speech.speaker: ROD.
speech.line: I do follow here in the chase, not like a hound that hunts, but one that fills up the cry. My money is almost spent; I have been tonight exceedingly well cudgell’d; and I think the issue will be, I shall have so much experience for my pains; and so, with no money at all and a little more wit, return again to Venice.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: How poor are they that have not patience!
What wound did ever heal but by degrees?
Thou know’st we work by wit, and not by witchcraft,
And wit depends on dilatory time.
Does’t not go well? Cassio hath beaten thee,
And thou by that small hurt hast cashier’d Cassio.
Though other things grow fair against the sun,
Yet fruits that blossom first will first be ripe.
Content thyself a while. By the mass, ’tis morning;
Pleasure and action make the hours seem short.
Retire thee, go where thou art billeted.
Away, I say, thou shalt know more hereafter.
Nay, get thee gone.
Two things are to be done:
My wife must move for Cassio to her mistress—
I’ll set her on—
Myself a while to draw the Moor apart,
And bring him jump when he may Cassio find
Soliciting his wife. Ay, that’s the way;
Dull not device by coldness and delay.

scene.scenedescription: Cassio pays some musicians to serenade Othello, but a clown arrives to tell them that the general is in no mood for music, and pays them to stop. Cassio asks him to fetch Emilia. Iago, passing by, says he will send Emilia in himself, and promises to occupy Othello so that Cassio can speak to Desdemona uninterrupted. Emilia comes in to tell Cassio that Desdemona has already spoken for him, but that Othello is arguing that it would harm his reputation to restore Cassio. Nevertheless, she agrees to get him some time with Desdemona.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: Masters, play here, I will content your pains; Something that’s brief; and bid “Good morrow, general.”

scene.stagedir: They play, and enter the Clown.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Why, masters, have your instruments been in Naples, that they speak i’ th’ nose thus?

speech.speaker: 1. MUS.
speech.line: How, sir? How?

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Are these, I pray you, wind instruments?

speech.speaker: 1. MUS.
speech.line: Ay, marry, are they, sir.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: O, thereby hangs a tail.

speech.speaker: 1. MUS.
speech.line: Whereby hangs a tale, sir?

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Marry, sir, by many a wind instrument that I know. But, masters, here’s money for you; and the general so likes your music, that he desires you for love’s sake to make no more noise with it.

speech.speaker: 1. MUS.
speech.line: Well, sir, we will not.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: If you have any music that may not be heard, to’t again; but (as they say) to hear music the general does not greatly care.

speech.speaker: 1. MUS.
speech.line: We have none such, sir.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: Then put up your pipes in your bag, for I’ll away. Go, vanish into air, away!

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: Dost thou hear, mine honest friend?

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: No, I hear not your honest friend; I hear you.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: Prithee keep up thy quillets. There’s a poor piece of gold for thee. If the gentlewoman that attends the general’s wife be stirring, tell her there’s one Cassio entreats her a little favor of speech. Wilt thou do this?

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: She is stirring, sir. If she will stir hither, I shall seem to notify unto her.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: Do, good my friend.
In happy time, Iago.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: You have not been a-bed then?

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: Why, no; the day had broke
Before we parted. I have made bold, Iago,
To send in to your wife. My suit to her
Is that she will to virtuous Desdemona
Procure me some access.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: I’ll send her to you presently;
And I’ll devise a mean to draw the Moor
Out of the way, that your converse and business
May be more free.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: I humbly thank you for’t.
I never knew a Florentine more kind and honest.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: Good morrow, good lieutenant. I am sorry
For your displeasure; but all will sure be well.
The general and his wife are talking of it,
And she speaks for you stoutly. The Moor replies
That he you hurt is of great fame in Cyprus,
And great affinity; and that in wholesome wisdom
He might not but refuse you. But he protests he loves you,
And needs no other suitor but his likings
To take the safest occasion by the front
To bring you in again.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: Yet I beseech you,
If you think fit, or that it may be done,
Give me advantage of some brief discourse
With Desdemon alone.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: Pray you come in.
I will bestow you where you shall have time
To speak your bosom freely.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: I am much bound to you.

scene.scenelocation: Cyprus. A room in the castle.
scene.scenedescription: Othello gives Iago letters to send off to Venice, and leaves to examine the forts of Cyprus.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: These letters give, Iago, to the pilot,
And by him do my duties to the Senate.
That done, I will be walking on the works;
Repair there to me.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Well, my good lord, I’ll do’t.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: This fortification, gentlemen, shall we see’t?

speech.speaker: GENTLEMEN.
speech.line: We’ll wait upon your lordship.

scene.scenelocation: Cyprus. The garden of the castle.
scene.scenedescription: Desdemona assures Cassio she will do all she can for him. Cassio leaves when he sees Othello and Iago approach, as he is too embarrassed to stay and hear Desdemona argue for him. Seeing Cassio leave, Iago mutters that he does not like this, but refuses to explain what he means to Othello; he insists that it cannot have been Cassio near Desdemona, since Cassio has no reason to look so guilty. Desdemona comes and pesters Othello about Cassio, and the general finally promises to see Cassio when she pleases after she insists she’ll give him no peace until he does so. She leaves after this fervent pleading, and Iago makes the most of the opportunity. Appearing to be reticent, he slowly expresses his worries that Cassio and Desdemona may be too familiar with each other. Othello forces him to explain what he means, and though Iago repeats that this may only be his imagination, and warns the general against jealousy, he brings Othello to believe that Desdemona and Cassio may be having an affair. So sure is Othello of Iago’s honesty that he credits his insinuations, though the sight of Desdemona leads him to doubt his own thoughts. Desdemona returns to find her husband in a very different temper from when she last saw him; when he complains of a pain on his forehead (his cuckold’s horns), she offers to bind it with her handkerchief, but he dismisses it as too small. The handkerchief falls to the floor, and Emilia picks it up, happy to have found it, since Iago has often asked her to steal it for him. She gives it to Iago, though he refuses to tell her what he plans to do with it. To himself he plans to lose the handkerchief in Cassio’s room, to become a physical proof to Othello. The general returns, distracted, unable to take his mind off his suspicions. Convincing himself, he bids farewell to his happiness, and rages at Iago, telling him to provide genuine proof of his allegations. Iago asks what sort of proof he can provide, pointing out that direct evidence would be hard to come by. He claims, however, that he recently heard Cassio speak in his sleep as if to Desdemona, and Othello takes this as proof. What’s more, says Iago, he recently saw Cassio wipe his face with the handkerchief that was Othello’s first gift to his wife. Othello swears to kill them both, and Iago vows to help him. Othello officially makes Iago his lieutenant.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: Be thou assur’d, good Cassio, I will do
All my abilities in thy behalf.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: Good madam, do. I warrant it grieves my husband
As if the cause were his.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: O, that’s an honest fellow. Do not doubt, Cassio,
But I will have my lord and you again
As friendly as you were.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: Bounteous madam,
What ever shall become of Michael Cassio,
He’s never any thing but your true servant.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: I know’t; I thank you. You do love my lord;
You have known him long, and be you well assur’d
He shall in strangeness stand no farther off
Than in a politic distance.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: Ay, but, lady,
That policy may either last so long,
Or feed upon such nice and waterish diet,
Or breed itself so out of circumstances,
That I being absent and my place supplied,
My general will forget my love and service.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: Do not doubt that; before Emilia here,
I give thee warrant of thy place. Assure thee,
If I do vow a friendship, I’ll perform it
To the last article. My lord shall never rest,
I’ll watch him tame, and talk him out of patience;
His bed shall seem a school, his board a shrift,
I’ll intermingle every thing he does
With Cassio’s suit. Therefore be merry, Cassio,
For thy solicitor shall rather die
Than give thy cause away.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: Madam, here comes my lord.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: Madam, I’ll take my leave.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: Why, stay, and hear me speak.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: Madam, not now; I am very ill at ease,
Unfit for mine own purposes.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: Well, do your discretion.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Hah? I like not that.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: What dost thou say?

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Nothing, my lord; or if—I know not what.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Was not that Cassio parted from my wife?

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Cassio, my lord? No, sure, I cannot think it,
That he would steal away so guilty-like,
Seeing your coming.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: I do believe ’twas he.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: How now, my lord?
I have been talking with a suitor here,
A man that languishes in your displeasure.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Who is’t you mean?

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: Why, your lieutenant, Cassio. Good my lord,
If I have any grace or power to move you,
His present reconciliation take;
For if he be not one that truly loves you,
That errs in ignorance and not in cunning,
I have no judgment in an honest face.
I prithee call him back.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Went he hence now?

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: Yes, faith; so humbled
That he hath left part of his grief with me
To suffer with him. Good love, call him back.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Not now, sweet Desdemon, some other time.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: But shall’t be shortly?

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: The sooner, sweet, for you.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: Shall’t be tonight at supper?

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: No, not tonight.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: Tomorrow dinner then?

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: I shall not dine at home;
I meet the captains at the citadel.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: Why then tomorrow night, or Tuesday morn;
On Tuesday noon, or night; on We’n’sday morn.
I prithee name the time, but let it not
Exceed three days. In faith, he’s penitent;
And yet his trespass, in our common reason
(Save that they say the wars must make example
Out of her best), is not almost a fault
T’ incur a private check. When shall he come?
Tell me, Othello. I wonder in my soul
What you would ask me that I should deny,
Or stand so mamm’ring on. What? Michael Cassio,
That came a-wooing with you, and so many a time,
When I have spoke of you dispraisingly,
Hath ta’en your part—to have so much to do
To bring him in! By’r lady, I could do much—

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Prithee no more; let him come when he will;
I will deny thee nothing.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: Why, this is not a boon;
’Tis as I should entreat you wear your gloves,
Or feed on nourishing dishes, or keep you warm,
Or sue to you to do a peculiar profit
To your own person. Nay, when I have a suit
Wherein I mean to touch your love indeed,
It shall be full of poise and difficult weight,
And fearful to be granted.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: I will deny thee nothing;
Whereon, I do beseech thee, grant me this,
To leave me but a little to myself.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: Shall I deny you? No. Farewell, my lord.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Farewell, my Desdemona, I’ll come to thee straight.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: Emilia, come.—Be as your fancies teach you;
What e’er you be, I am obedient.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Excellent wretch! Perdition catch my soul
But I do love thee! And when I love thee not,
Chaos is come again.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: My noble lord—

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: What dost thou say, Iago?

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Did Michael Cassio, when you woo’d my lady,
Know of your love?

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: He did, from first to last. Why dost thou ask?

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: But for a satisfaction of my thought,
No further harm.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Why of thy thought, Iago?

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: I did not think he had been acquainted with her.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: O yes, and went between us very oft.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Indeed!

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Indeed? Ay, indeed. Discern’st thou aught in that?
Is he not honest?

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Honest, my lord?

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Honest? Ay, honest.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: My lord, for aught I know.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: What dost thou think?

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Think, my lord?

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Think, my lord? By heaven, thou echo’st me,
As if there were some monster in thy thought
Too hideous to be shown. Thou dost mean something.
I heard thee say even now, thou lik’st not that,
When Cassio left my wife. What didst not like?
And when I told thee he was of my counsel
In my whole course of wooing, thou criedst, “Indeed!”
And didst contract and purse thy brow together,
As if thou then hadst shut up in thy brain
Some horrible conceit. If thou dost love me,
Show me thy thought.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: My lord, you know I love you.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: I think thou dost;
And for I know thou’rt full of love and honesty,
And weigh’st thy words before thou giv’st them breath,
Therefore these stops of thine fright me the more;
For such things in a false disloyal knave
Are tricks of custom; but in a man that’s just
They’re close dilations, working from the heart,
That passion cannot rule.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: For Michael Cassio,
I dare be sworn I think that he is honest.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: I think so too.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Men should be what they seem,
Or those that be not, would they might seem none!

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Certain, men should be what they seem.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Why then I think Cassio’s an honest man.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Nay, yet there’s more in this.
I prithee speak to me as to thy thinkings,
As thou dost ruminate, and give thy worst of thoughts
The worst of words.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Good my lord, pardon me:
Though I am bound to every act of duty,
I am not bound to that all slaves are free to.
Utter my thoughts? Why, say they are vild and false,
As where’s that palace whereinto foul things
Sometimes intrude not? Who has that breast so pure
But some uncleanly apprehensions
Keep leets and law-days and in sessions sit
With meditations lawful?

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Thou dost conspire against thy friend, Iago,
If thou but think’st him wrong’d, and mak’st his ear
A stranger to thy thoughts.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: I do beseech you,
Though I perchance am vicious in my guess
(As I confess it is my nature’s plague
To spy into abuses, and oft my jealousy
Shapes faults that are not), that your wisdom then,
From one that so imperfectly conjects,
Would take no notice, nor build yourself a trouble
Out of his scattering and unsure observance.
It were not for your quiet nor your good,
Nor for my manhood, honesty, and wisdom,
To let you know my thoughts.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: ’Zounds, what dost thou mean?

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Good name in man and woman, dear my lord,
Is the immediate jewel of their souls.
Who steals my purse steals trash; ’tis something, nothing;
’Twas mine, ’tis his, and has been slave to thousands;
But he that filches from me my good name
Robs me of that which not enriches him,
And makes me poor indeed.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: By heaven, I’ll know thy thoughts.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: You cannot, if my heart were in your hand,
Nor shall not, whilst ’tis in my custody.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Ha?

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: O, beware, my lord, of jealousy!
It is the green-ey’d monster which doth mock
The meat it feeds on. That cuckold lives in bliss
Who, certain of his fate, loves not his wronger;
But O, what damned minutes tells he o’er
Who dotes, yet doubts; suspects, yet strongly loves!

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: O misery!

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Poor and content is rich, and rich enough,
But riches fineless is as poor as winter
To him that ever fears he shall be poor.
Good God, the souls of all my tribe defend
From jealousy!

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Why? Why is this?
Think’st thou I’d make a life of jealousy?
To follow still the changes of the moon
With fresh suspicions? No! To be once in doubt
Is once to be resolv’d. Exchange me for a goat,
When I shall turn the business of my soul
To such exsufflicate and blown surmises,
Matching thy inference. ’Tis not to make me jealous
To say my wife is fair, feeds well, loves company,
Is free of speech, sings, plays, and dances well;
Where virtue is, these are more virtuous.
Nor from mine own weak merits will I draw
The smallest fear or doubt of her revolt,
For she had eyes, and chose me. No, Iago,
I’ll see before I doubt; when I doubt, prove;
And on the proof, there is no more but this—
Away at once with love or jealousy!

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: I am glad of this, for now I shall have reason
To show the love and duty that I bear you
With franker spirit; therefore (as I am bound)
Receive it from me. I speak not yet of proof.
Look to your wife, observe her well with Cassio,
Wear your eyes thus, not jealous nor secure.
I would not have your free and noble nature,
Out of self-bounty, be abus’d; look to’t.
I know our country disposition well:
In Venice they do let God see the pranks
They dare not show their husbands; their best conscience
Is not to leave’t undone, but keep’t unknown.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Dost thou say so?

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: She did deceive her father, marrying you,
And when she seem’d to shake and fear your looks,
She lov’d them most.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: And so she did.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Why, go to then.
She that so young could give out such a seeming
To seel her father’s eyes up, close as oak,
He thought ’twas witchcraft—but I am much to blame;
I humbly do beseech you of your pardon
For too much loving you.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: I am bound to thee forever.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: I see this hath a little dash’d your spirits.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Not a jot, not a jot.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: I’ faith, I fear it has.
I hope you will consider what is spoke
Comes from my love. But I do see y’ are mov’d.
I am to pray you not to strain my speech
To grosser issues nor to larger reach
Than to suspicion.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: I will not.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Should you do so, my lord,
My speech should fall into such vild success
Which my thoughts aim’d not. Cassio’s my worthy friend—
My lord, I see y’ are mov’d.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: No, not much mov’d:
I do not think but Desdemona’s honest.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Long live she so! And long live you to think so!

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: And yet how nature erring from itself—

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Ay, there’s the point; as (to be bold with you)
Not to affect many proposed matches
Of her own clime, complexion, and degree,
Whereto we see in all things nature tends—
Foh, one may smell in such, a will most rank,
Foul disproportions, thoughts unnatural.
But (pardon me) I do not in position
Distinctly speak of her, though I may fear
Her will, recoiling to her better judgment,
May fall to match you with her country forms,
And happily repent.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Farewell, farewell!
If more thou dost perceive, let me know more;
Set on thy wife to observe. Leave me, Iago.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: My lord, I take my leave.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Why did I marry? This honest creature, doubtless,
Sees and knows more, much more, than he unfolds.
speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: My lord, I would I might entreat your honor
To scan this thing no farther; leave it to time.
Although ’tis fit that Cassio have his place—
For sure he fills it up with great ability—
Yet if you please to hold him off awhile,
You shall by that perceive him and his means.
Note if your lady strain his entertainment
With any strong or vehement importunity;
Much will be seen in that. In the mean time,
Let me be thought too busy in my fears
(As worthy cause I have to fear I am)
And hold her free, I do beseech your honor.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Fear not my government.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: I once more take my leave.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: This fellow’s of exceeding honesty,
And knows all qualities, with a learned spirit,
Of human dealings. If I do prove her haggard,
Though that her jesses were my dear heart-strings,
I’ld whistle her off, and let her down the wind
To prey at fortune. Haply, for I am black,
And have not those soft parts of conversation
That chamberers have, or for I am declin’d
Into the vale of years (yet that’s not much),
She’s gone. I am abus’d, and my relief
Must be to loathe her. O curse of marriage!
That we can call these delicate creatures ours,
And not their appetites! I had rather be a toad
And live upon the vapor of a dungeon
Than keep a corner in the thing I love
For others’ uses. Yet ’tis the plague of great ones,
Prerogativ’d are they less than the base;
’Tis destiny unshunnable, like death.
Even then this forked plague is fated to us
When we do quicken. Look where she comes:
If she be false, O then heaven mocks itself!
I’ll not believe’t.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: How now, my dear Othello?
Your dinner, and the generous islanders
By you invited, do attend your presence.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: I am to blame.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: Why do you speak so faintly?
Are you not well?

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: I have a pain upon my forehead, here.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: Faith, that’s with watching, ’twill away again.
Let me but bind it hard, within this hour
It will be well.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Your napkin is too little;
speech.stagedir: He puts the handkerchief from him, and it drops.
speech.line: Let it alone. Come, I’ll go in with you.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: I am very sorry that you are not well.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: I am glad I have found this napkin;
This was her first remembrance from the Moor.
My wayward husband hath a hundred times
Woo’d me to steal it; but she so loves the token
(For he conjur’d her she should ever keep it)
That she reserves it evermore about her
To kiss and talk to. I’ll have the work ta’en out,
And give’t Iago. What he will do with it
Heaven knows, not I;
I nothing but to please his fantasy.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: How now? What do you here alone?

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: Do not you chide; I have a thing for you.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: You have a thing for me? It is a common thing—

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: Hah?

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: To have a foolish wife.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: O, is that all? What will you give me now
For that same handkerchief?

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: What handkerchief?

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: What handkerchief?
Why, that the Moor first gave to Desdemona,
That which so often you did bid me steal.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Hast stol’n it from her?

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: No, faith; she let it drop by negligence,
And to th’ advantage, I, being here, took’t up.
Look, here ’tis.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: A good wench, give it me.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: What will you do with’t, that you have been so earnest
To have me filch it?

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Why, what is that to you?

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: If it be not for some purpose of import,
Give’t me again. Poor lady, she’ll run mad
When she shall lack it.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Be not acknown on’t; I have use for it.
Go, leave me.
I will in Cassio’s lodging lose this napkin,
And let him find it. Trifles light as air
Are to the jealous confirmations strong
As proofs of holy writ; this may do something.
The Moor already changes with my poison:
Dangerous conceits are in their natures poisons,
Which at the first are scarce found to distaste,
But with a little act upon the blood
Burn like the mines of sulphur.
I did say so.
Look where he comes! Not poppy, nor mandragora,
Nor all the drowsy syrups of the world
Shall ever medicine thee to that sweet sleep
Which thou ow’dst yesterday.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Ha, ha, false to me?

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Why, how now, general? No more of that.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Avaunt, be gone! Thou hast set me on the rack.
I swear ’tis better to be much abus’d
Than but to know’t a little.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: How now, my lord?

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: What sense had I in her stol’n hours of lust?
I saw’t not, thought it not; it harm’d not me.
I slept the next night well, fed well, was free and merry;
I found not Cassio’s kisses on her lips.
He that is robb’d, not wanting what is stol’n,
Let him not know’t, and he’s not robb’d at all.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: I am sorry to hear this.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: I had been happy, if the general camp,
Pioners and all, had tasted her sweet body,
So I had nothing known. O now, forever
Farewell the tranquil mind! Farewell content!
Farewell the plumed troops and the big wars
That makes ambition virtue! O, farewell!
Farewell the neighing steed and the shrill trump,
The spirit-stirring drum, th’ ear-piercing fife,
The royal banner, and all quality,
Pride, pomp, and circumstance of glorious war!
And O you mortal engines, whose rude throats
Th’ immortal Jove’s dread clamors counterfeit,
Farewell! Othello’s occupation’s gone.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Is’t possible, my lord?

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Villain, be sure thou prove my love a whore;
Be sure of it. Give me the ocular proof,
Or by the worth of mine eternal soul,
Thou hadst been better have been born a dog
Than answer my wak’d wrath!

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Is’t come to this?

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Make me to see’t; or (at the least) so prove it
That the probation bear no hinge nor loop
To hang a doubt on; or woe upon thy life!

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: My noble lord—

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: If thou dost slander her and torture me,
Never pray more; abandon all remorse;
On horror’s head horrors accumulate;
Do deeds to make heaven weep, all earth amaz’d;
For nothing canst thou to damnation add
Greater than that.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: O grace! O heaven forgive me!
Are you a man? Have you a soul? Or sense?
God buy you; take mine office. O wretched fool,
That lov’st to make thine honesty a vice!
O monstrous world! Take note, take note, O world,
To be direct and honest is not safe.
I thank you for this profit, and from hence
I’ll love no friend, sith love breeds such offense.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Nay, stay. Thou shouldst be honest.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: I should be wise—for honesty’s a fool
And loses that it works for.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: By the world,
I think my wife be honest, and think she is not;
I think that thou art just, and think thou art not.
I’ll have some proof. Her name, that was as fresh
As Dian’s visage, is now begrim’d and black
As mine own face. If there be cords, or knives,
Poison, or fire, or suffocating streams,
I’ll not endure it. Would I were satisfied!

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: I see, sir, you are eaten up with passion;
I do repent me that I put it to you.
You would be satisfied?

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Would? Nay, and I will.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: And may; but how? How satisfied, my lord?
Would you, the supervisor, grossly gape on?
Behold her topp’d?

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Death and damnation! O!

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: It were a tedious difficulty, I think,
To bring them to that prospect; damn them then,
If ever mortal eyes do see them bolster
More than their own. What then? How then?
What shall I say? Where’s satisfaction?
It is impossible you should see this,
Were they as prime as goats, as hot as monkeys,
As salt as wolves in pride, and fools as gross
As ignorance made drunk. But yet, I say,
If imputation and strong circumstances
Which lead directly to the door of truth
Will give you satisfaction, you might have’t.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Give me a living reason she’s disloyal.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: I do not like the office;
But sith I am ent’red in this cause so far
(Prick’d to’t by foolish honesty and love),
I will go on. I lay with Cassio lately,
And being troubled with a raging tooth,
I could not sleep.
There are a kind of men, so loose of soul,
That in their sleeps will mutter their affairs;
One of this kind is Cassio.
In sleep I heard him say, “Sweet Desdemona,
Let us be wary, let us hide our loves”;
And then, sir, would he gripe and wring my hand;
Cry, “O sweet creature!” then kiss me hard,
As if he pluck’d up kisses by the roots
That grew upon my lips; then laid his leg
Over my thigh, and sigh’d, and kiss’d, and then
Cried, “Cursed fate that gave thee to the Moor!”

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: O monstrous! Monstrous!

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Nay, this was but his dream.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: But this denoted a foregone conclusion.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: ’Tis a shrewd doubt, though it be but a dream,
And this may help to thicken other proofs
That do demonstrate thinly.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: I’ll tear her all to pieces.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Nay, yet be wise; yet we see nothing done;
She may be honest yet. Tell me but this,
Have you not sometimes seen a handkerchief
Spotted with strawberries in your wive’s hand?

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: I gave her such a one; ’twas my first gift.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: I know not that; but such a handkerchief
(I am sure it was your wive’s) did I today
See Cassio wipe his beard with.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: If it be that—

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: If it be that, or any that was hers,
It speaks against her with the other proofs.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: O that the slave had forty thousand lives!
One is too poor, too weak for my revenge.
Now do I see ’tis true. Look here, Iago,
All my fond love thus do I blow to heaven.
’Tis gone.
Arise, black vengeance, from the hollow hell!
Yield up, O love, thy crown and hearted throne
To tyrannous hate! Swell, bosom, with thy fraught,
For ’tis of aspics’ tongues!

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Yet be content.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: O blood, blood, blood!

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Patience, I say; your mind perhaps may change.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Never, Iago. Like to the Pontic Sea,
Whose icy current and compulsive course
Nev’r feels retiring ebb, but keeps due on
To the Propontic and the Hellespont,
Even so my bloody thoughts, with violent pace,
Shall nev’r look back, nev’r ebb to humble love,
Till that a capable and wide revenge
Swallow them up.
Now by yond marble heaven,
In the due reverence of a sacred vow
I here engage my words.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Do not rise yet.
Witness, you ever-burning lights above,
You elements that clip us round about,
Witness that here Iago doth give up
The execution of his wit, hands, heart,
To wrong’d Othello’s service! Let him command,
And to obey shall be in me remorse,
What bloody business ever.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: I greet thy love,
Not with vain thanks, but with acceptance bounteous,
And will upon the instant put thee to’t:
Within these three days let me hear thee say
That Cassio’s not alive.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: My friend is dead; ’tis done at your request.
But let her live.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Damn her, lewd minx! O, damn her, damn her!
Come go with me apart, I will withdraw
To furnish me with some swift means of death
For the fair devil. Now art thou my lieutenant.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: I am your own forever.

scene.scenepersonae: (Desdemona, Emilia, Clown, Othello, Iago, Cassio, Bianca)
scene.scenedescription: Desdemona sends the clown to fetch Cassio. She is worried about having lost her handkerchief, but Emilia does not tell her what she knows where it has gone. Still, Desdemona insists that Othello is not the jealous type, and states her determination to nag him until he restores Cassio to his position as lieutenant. Othello comes in, and when Desdemona asks him about Cassio, he claims to have a cold and asks to borrow her handkerchief. Desdemona says she doesn’t have it on her, and he tells her off for it, saying that it is a magical handkerchief, the loss of which will make him hate her. Desdemona is horrified at the thought, and Othello accuses her of losing it; she says that she simply left it at home. She tries to get him off his obsession with the handkerchief by bringing up Cassio again, but this merely enrages him until he stalks away. Desdemona is hurt, while Emilia expresses her low opinion of men. Cassio and Iago appear, Cassio asking Desdemona again for her help, but she has to explain that Othello is not himself. Iago pretends concern and goes off to find out what the matter is. Desdemona chides herself for bothering Othello when clearly some matter of state is occupying his thoughts, though Emilia is skeptical. The ladies leave. Cassio meets his lady-friend Bianca, who is angry with him for leaving her alone for so long; he asks her to take out the embroidery of the handkerchief he found in his room, and she accuses him of having a new lover. He tells her to be quiet and asks her to leave him alone, not wanting Othello to see him with a woman in case it hurts his suit. He promises to see her soon.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: Do you know, sirrah, where Lieutenant Cassio lies?

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: I dare not say he lies any where.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: Why, man?

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: He’s a soldier, and for me to say a soldier lies, ’tis stabbing.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: Go to! Where lodges he?

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: To tell you where he lodges, is to tell you where I lie.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: Can any thing be made of this?

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: I know not where he lodges, and for me to devise a lodging and say he lies here, or he lies there, were to lie in mine own throat.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: Can you inquire him out, and be edified by report?

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: I will catechize the world for him, that is, make questions, and by them answer.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: Seek him, bid him come hither. Tell him I have mov’d my lord on his behalf, and hope all will be well.

speech.speaker: CLO.
speech.line: To do this is within the compass of man’s wit, and therefore I will attempt the doing it.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: Where should I lose the handkerchief, Emilia?

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: I know not, madam.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: Believe me, I had rather have lost my purse
Full of crusadoes; and but my noble Moor
Is true of mind, and made of no such baseness
As jealous creatures are, it were enough
To put him to ill thinking.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: Is he not jealous?

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: Who, he? I think the sun where he was born
Drew all such humors from him.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: Look where he comes.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: I will not leave him now till Cassio
Be call’d to him.—How is’t with you, my lord?

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Well, my good lady.
O, hardness to dissemble!—
How do you, Desdemona?

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: Well, my good lord.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Give me your hand. This hand is moist, my lady.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: It yet hath felt no age nor known no sorrow.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: This argues fruitfulness and liberal heart;
Hot, hot, and moist. This hand of yours requires
A sequester from liberty: fasting and prayer,
Much castigation, exercise devout,
For here’s a young and sweating devil here
That commonly rebels. ’Tis a good hand,
A frank one.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: You may, indeed, say so;
For ’twas that hand that gave away my heart.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: A liberal hand. The hearts of old gave hands;
But our new heraldry is hands, not hearts.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: I cannot speak of this. Come now, your promise.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: What promise, chuck?

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: I have sent to bid Cassio come speak with you.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: I have a salt and sorry rheum offends me;
Lend me thy handkerchief.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: Here, my lord.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: That which I gave you.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: I have it not about me.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Not?

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: No, faith, my lord.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: That’s a fault. That handkerchief
Did an Egyptian to my mother give;
She was a charmer, and could almost read
The thoughts of people. She told her, while she kept it,
’Twould make her amiable, and subdue my father
Entirely to her love; but if she lost it,
Or made a gift of it, my father’s eye
Should hold her loathed, and his spirits should hunt
After new fancies. She, dying, gave it me,
And bid me, when my fate would have me wiv’d,
To give it her. I did so; and take heed on’t,
Make it a darling like your precious eye.
To lose’t or give’t away were such perdition
As nothing else could match.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: Is’t possible?

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: ’Tis true; there’s magic in the web of it.
A sibyl, that had numb’red in the world
The sun to course two hundred compasses,
In her prophetic fury sew’d the work;
The worms were hallowed that did breed the silk,
And it was dy’d in mummy which the skillful
Conserv’d of maidens’ hearts.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: I’ faith! Is’t true?

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Most veritable, therefore look to’t well.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: Then would to God that I had never seen’t!

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Ha? Wherefore?

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: Why do you speak so startingly and rash?

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Is’t lost? Is’t gone? Speak, is’t out o’ th’ way?

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: Heaven bless us!

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Say you?

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: It is not lost; but what and if it were?

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: How?

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: I say, it is not lost.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Fetch’t, let me see’t.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: Why, so I can, sir, but I will not now.
This is a trick to put me from my suit.
Pray you let Cassio be receiv’d again.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Fetch me the handkerchief, my mind misgives.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: Come, come;
You’ll never meet a more sufficient man.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: The handkerchief!

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: I pray talk me of Cassio.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: The handkerchief!

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: A man that all his time
Hath founded his good fortunes on your love,
Shar’d dangers with you—

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: The handkerchief!

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: I’ faith, you are to blame.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: ’Zounds!

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: Is not this man jealous?

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: I nev’r saw this before.
Sure, there’s some wonder in this handkerchief;
I am most unhappy in the loss of it.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: ’Tis not a year or two shows us a man:
They are all but stomachs, and we all but food;
They eat us hungerly, and when they are full
They belch us.
Look you, Cassio and my husband!

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: There is no other way: ’tis she must do’t;
And lo the happiness! Go, and importune her.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: How now, good Cassio, what’s the news with you?

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: Madam, my former suit. I do beseech you
That by your virtuous means I may again
Exist, and be a member of his love
Whom I, with all the office of my heart,
Entirely honor. I would not be delay’d.
If my offense be of such mortal kind
That nor my service past, nor present sorrows,
Nor purpos’d merit in futurity,
Can ransom me into his love again,
But to know so must be my benefit;
So shall I clothe me in a forc’d content,
And shut myself up in some other course,
To fortune’s alms.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: Alas, thrice-gentle Cassio,
My advocation is not now in tune.
My lord is not my lord; nor should I know him
Were he in favor as in humor alter’d.
So help me every spirit sanctified,
As I have spoken for you all my best,
And stood within the blank of his displeasure
For my free speech! You must awhile be patient.
What I can do, I will; and more I will
Than for myself I dare. Let that suffice you.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Is my lord angry?

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: He went hence but now;
And certainly in strange unquietness.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Can he be angry? I have seen the cannon
When it hath blown his ranks into the air,
And like the devil from his very arm
Puff’d his own brother—and is he angry?
Something of moment then. I will go meet him.
There’s matter in’t indeed, if he be angry.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: I prithee do so.
Something sure of state,
Either from Venice, or some unhatch’d practice
Made demonstrable here in Cyprus to him,
Hath puddled his clear spirit; and in such cases
Men’s natures wrangle with inferior things,
Though great ones are their object. ’Tis even so;
For let our finger ache, and it endues
Our other healthful members even to a sense
Of pain. Nay, we must think men are not gods,
Nor of them look for such observancy
As fits the bridal. Beshrew me much, Emilia,
I was (unhandsome warrior as I am)
Arraigning his unkindness with my soul;
But now I find I had suborn’d the witness,
And he’s indicted falsely.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: Pray heaven it be state matters, as you think,
And no conception nor no jealous toy
Concerning you.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: Alas the day, I never gave him cause.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: But jealous souls will not be answer’d so;
They are not ever jealous for the cause,
But jealous for they’re jealous. It is a monster
Begot upon itself, born on itself.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: Heaven keep the monster from Othello’s mind!

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: Lady, amen.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: I will go seek him. Cassio, walk hereabout;
If I do find him fit, I’ll move your suit
And seek to effect it to my uttermost.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: I humbly thank your ladyship.

speech.speaker: BIAN.
speech.line: ’Save you, friend Cassio!

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: What make you from home?
How is’t with you, my most fair Bianca?
I’faith, sweet love, I was coming to your house.

speech.speaker: BIAN.
speech.line: And I was going to your lodging, Cassio.
What? Keep a week away? Seven days and nights?
Eightscore eight hours? And lovers’ absent hours,
More tedious than the dial eightscore times?
O weary reck’ning!

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: Pardon me, Bianca.
I have this while with leaden thoughts been press’d,
But I shall in a more continuate time
Strike off this score of absence. Sweet Bianca,
Take me this work out.

speech.speaker: BIAN.
speech.line: O Cassio, whence came this?
This is some token from a newer friend;
To the felt absence now I feel a cause.
Is’t come to this? Well, well.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: Go to, woman!
Throw your vild guesses in the devil’s teeth,
From whence you have them. You are jealous now
That this is from some mistress, some remembrance;
No, by my faith, Bianca.

speech.speaker: BIAN.
speech.line: Why, whose is it?

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: I know not, neither; I found it in my chamber.
I like the work well; ere it be demanded
(As like enough it will) I would have it copied.
Take it, and do’t, and leave me for this time.

speech.speaker: BIAN.
speech.line: Leave you? Wherefore?

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: I do attend here on the general,
And think it no addition, nor my wish,
To have him see me woman’d.

speech.speaker: BIAN.
speech.line: Why, I pray you?

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: Not that I love you not.

speech.speaker: BIAN.
speech.line: But that you do not love me.
I pray you bring me on the way a little,
And say if I shall see you soon at night.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: ’Tis but a little way that I can bring you,
For I attend here; but I’ll see you soon.

speech.speaker: BIAN.
speech.line: ’Tis very good; I must be circumstanc’d.

scene.scenepersonae: (Othello, Iago, Cassio, Bianca, Lodovico, Desdemona, and Attendants)
scene.scenedescription: Iago continues to torment Othello, dropping suggestions into his ear while arguing that they are not great transgressions, which just works Othello up even more. He finally pushes Othello so far that the general becomes incoherent and finally falls down into a trance. Cassio enters and is concerned, but Iago tells him it’s merely an epileptic fit and asks him to leave. Reviving Othello, he proposes to have a chat with Cassio about Desdemona, letting Othello overhear. Othello agrees. What Iago actually does is talk to Cassio about Bianca, walking about so that Othello can only hear portions of the discussion. Cassio’s laughter as he mocks Bianca enrages Othello; even worse, Bianca herself arrives to rant at Cassio about the handkerchief, and Othello sees that Cassio has given that precious keepsake to a prostitute. Cassio runs after Bianca; Othello is now determined to kill both Cassio and Desdemona. Iago offers to take care of Cassio, recommending that Othello strangle Desdemona in her bed. Desdemona’s cousin Lodovico arrives from Venice with letters from the Senate that call Othello home and name Cassio the new governor of Cyprus. As Desdemona explains the situation to Lodovico, Othello hears her praises of Cassio and gets so worked up that he strikes out at her, to Lodovico’s amazement. When the Venetian protests and asks him to apologize to her, he merely sneers at her sarcastically, orders her to go home, and leaves himself. Lodovico worries for his wits, and Iago implies that what he saw is by no means the worst.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Will you think so?

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Think so, Iago?

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: What,
To kiss in private?

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: An unauthoriz’d kiss!

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Or to be naked with her friend in bed
An hour, or more, not meaning any harm?

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Naked in bed, Iago, and not mean harm?
It is hypocrisy against the devil.
They that mean virtuously, and yet do so,
The devil their virtue tempts, and they tempt heaven.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: If they do nothing, ’tis a venial slip;
But if I give my wife a handkerchief—

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: What then?

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Why then ’tis hers, my lord, and being hers,
She may, I think, bestow’t on any man.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: She is protectress of her honor too;
May she give that?

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Her honor is an essence that’s not seen;
They have it very oft that have it not.
But for the handkerchief—

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: By heaven, I would most gladly have forgot it.
Thou saidst (O, it comes o’er my memory,
As doth the raven o’er the infectious house,
Boding to all) he had my handkerchief.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Ay; what of that?

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: That’s not so good now.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: What
If I had said I had seen him do you wrong?
Or heard him say—as knaves be such abroad,
Who having by their own importunate suit,
Or voluntary dotage of some mistress,
Convinced or supplied them, cannot choose
But they must blab—

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Hath he said any thing?

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: He hath, my lord, but be you well assur’d,
No more than he’ll unswear.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: What hath he said?

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Faith, that he did—I know not what he did.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: What? What?

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Lie—

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: With her?

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: With her? On her; what you will.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Lie with her? Lie on her? We say lie on her, when they belie her. Lie with her! ’Zounds, that’s fulsome! Handkerchief—confessions—handkerchief! To confess, and be hang’d for his labor—first to be hang’d, and then to confess. I tremble at it. Nature would not invest herself in such shadowing passion without some instruction. It is not words that shakes me thus. Pish! Noses, ears, and lips. Is’t possible? Confess? Handkerchief? O devil!

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Work on,
My medicine, work! Thus credulous fools are caught,
And many worthy and chaste dames even thus
(All guiltless) meet reproach.—What ho! My lord!
My lord, I say! Othello!
How now, Cassio?

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: What’s the matter?

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: My lord is fall’n into an epilepsy.
This is his second fit; he had one yesterday.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: Rub him about the temples.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: No, forbear,
The lethargy must have his quiet course;
If not, he foams at mouth, and by and by
Breaks out to savage madness. Look, he stirs.
Do you withdraw yourself a little while,
He will recover straight. When he is gone,
I would on great occasion speak with you.
How is it, general? Have you not hurt your head?

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Dost thou mock me?

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: I mock you not, by heaven.
Would you would bear your fortune like a man!

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: A horned man’s a monster and a beast.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: There’s many a beast then in a populous city,
And many a civil monster.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Did he confess it?

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Good sir, be a man;
Think every bearded fellow that’s but yok’d
May draw with you. There’s millions now alive
That nightly lie in those unproper beds
Which they dare swear peculiar; your case is better.
O, ’tis the spite of hell, the fiend’s arch-mock,
To lip a wanton in a secure couch,
And to suppose her chaste! No, let me know,
And knowing what I am, I know what she shall be.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: O, thou art wise; ’tis certain.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Stand you a while apart,
Confine yourself but in a patient list.
Whilst you were here o’erwhelmed with your grief
(A passion most unsuiting such a man),
Cassio came hither. I shifted him away,
And laid good ’scuses upon your ecstasy;
Bade him anon return and here speak with me,
The which he promis’d. Do but encave yourself,
And mark the fleers, the gibes, and notable scorns
That dwell in every region of his face,
For I will make him tell the tale anew:
Where, how, how oft, how long ago, and when
He hath, and is again to cope your wife.
I say, but mark his gesture. Marry, patience,
Or I shall say y’ are all in all in spleen,
And nothing of a man.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Dost thou hear, Iago,
I will be found most cunning in my patience;
But (dost thou hear) most bloody.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: That’s not amiss,
But yet keep time in all. Will you withdraw?
Now will I question Cassio of Bianca,
A huswife that by selling her desires
Buys herself bread and clothes. It is a creature
That dotes on Cassio (as ’tis the strumpet’s plague
To beguile many and be beguil’d by one);
He, when he hears of her, cannot restrain
From the excess of laughter. Here he comes.
As he shall smile, Othello shall go mad;
And his unbookish jealousy must construe
Poor Cassio’s smiles, gestures, and light behaviors
Quite in the wrong. How do you now, lieutenant?

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: The worser that you give me the addition
Whose want even kills me.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Ply Desdemona well, and you are sure on’t.
Now, if this suit lay in Bianca’s pow’r,
How quickly should you speed!

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: Alas, poor caitiff!

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Look how he laughs already!

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: I never knew woman love man so.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: Alas, poor rogue, I think, i’ faith, she loves me.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Now he denies it faintly, and laughs it out.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Do you hear, Cassio?

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Now he importunes him
To tell it o’er. Go to, well said, well said.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: She gives it out that you shall marry her.
Do you intend it?

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: Ha, ha, ha!

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Do you triumph, Roman? Do you triumph?

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: I marry her! What? A customer! Prithee bear some charity to my wit, do not think it so unwholesome. Ha, ha, ha!

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: So, so, so, so; they laugh that wins.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Faith, the cry goes that you marry her.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: Prithee say true.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: I am a very villain else.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Have you scor’d me? Well.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: This is the monkey’s own giving out. She is persuaded I will marry her, out of her own love and flattery, not out of my promise.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Iago beckons me; now he begins the story.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: She was here even now; she haunts me in every place. I was the other day talking on the sea-bank with certain Venetians, and thither comes the bauble, and by this hand, falls me thus about my neck—

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Crying, “O dear Cassio!” as it were; his gesture imports it.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: So hangs, and lolls, and weeps upon me; so hales and pulls me. Ha, ha, ha!

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Now he tells how she pluck’d him to my chamber. O, I see that nose of yours, but not that dog I shall throw it to.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: Well, I must leave her company.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Before me! Look where she comes.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: ’Tis such another fitchew! Marry, a perfum’d one!—What do you mean by this haunting of me?

speech.speaker: BIAN.
speech.line: Let the devil and his dam haunt you! What did you mean by that same handkerchief you gave me even now? I was a fine fool to take it. I must take out the work? A likely piece of work, that you should find it in your chamber, and know not who left it there! This is some minx’s token, and I must take out the work? There, give it your hobby-horse. Wheresoever you had it, I’ll take out no work on’t.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: How now, my sweet Bianca? How now? How now?

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: By heaven, that should be my handkerchief!

speech.speaker: BIAN.
speech.line: An’ you’ll come to supper tonight, you may; an’ you will not, come when you are next prepar’d for.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: After her, after her.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: Faith, I must, she’ll rail in the streets else.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Will you sup there?

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: Faith, I intend so.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Well, I may chance to see you; for I would very fain speak with you.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: Prithee come; will you?

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Go to; say no more.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: How shall I murder him, Iago?

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Did you perceive how he laugh’d at his vice?

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: O Iago!

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: And did you see the handkerchief?

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Was that mine?

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Yours, by this hand. And to see how he prizes the foolish woman your wife! She gave it him, and he hath giv’n it his whore.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: I would have him nine years a-killing. A fine woman! A fair woman! A sweet woman!

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Nay, you must forget that.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Ay, let her rot, and perish, and be damn’d tonight, for she shall not live. No, my heart is turn’d to stone; I strike it, and it hurts my hand. O, the world hath not a sweeter creature! She might lie by an emperor’s side and command him tasks.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Nay, that’s not your way.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Hang her, I do but say what she is. So delicate with her needle! An admirable musician! O, she will sing the savageness out of a bear. Of so high and plenteous wit and invention!

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: She’s the worse for all this.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: O, a thousand, a thousand times. And then of so gentle a condition!

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Ay, too gentle.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Nay, that’s certain. But yet the pity of it, Iago! O Iago, the pity of it, Iago!

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: If you are so fond over her iniquity, give her patent to offend, for if it touch not you, it comes near nobody.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: I will chop her into messes. Cuckold me!

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: O, ’tis foul in her.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: With mine officer!

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: That’s fouler.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Get me some poison, Iago, this night. I’ll not expostulate with her, lest her body and beauty unprovide my mind again. This night, Iago.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Do it not with poison; strangle her in her bed, even the bed she hath contaminated.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Good, good; the justice of it pleases; very good.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: And for Cassio, let me be his undertaker.
You shall hear more by midnight.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Excellent good.
What trumpet is that same?

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: I warrant, something from Venice.
’Tis Lodovico—
This comes from the Duke. See, your wife’s with him.

speech.speaker: LOD.
speech.line: God save you, worthy general!

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: With all my heart, sir.

speech.speaker: LOD.
speech.line: The Duke and the senators of Venice greet you.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: I kiss the instrument of their pleasures.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: And what’s the news, good cousin Lodovico?

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: I am very glad to see you, signior;
Welcome to Cyprus.

speech.speaker: LOD.
speech.line: I thank you. How does Lieutenant Cassio?

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Lives, sir.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: Cousin, there’s fall’n between him and my lord
An unkind breach; but you shall make all well.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Are you sure of that?

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: My lord?

line.recite: “This fail you not to do, as you will—”

speech.speaker: LOD.
speech.line: He did not call; he’s busy in the paper.
Is there division ’twixt my lord and Cassio?

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: A most unhappy one. I would do much
T’ atone them, for the love I bear to Cassio.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Fire and brimstone!

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: My lord?

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Are you wise?

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: What, is he angry?

speech.speaker: LOD.
speech.line: May be th’ letter mov’d him;
For as I think, they do command him home,
Deputing Cassio in his government.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: By my troth, I am glad on’t.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Indeed?

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: My lord?

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: I am glad to see you mad.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: Why, sweet Othello?

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Devil!

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: I have not deserv’d this.

speech.speaker: LOD.
speech.line: My lord, this would not be believ’d in Venice,
Though I should swear I saw’t. ’Tis very much,
Make her amends; she weeps.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: O devil, devil!
If that the earth could teem with woman’s tears,
Each drop she falls would prove a crocodile.
Out of my sight!

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: I will not stay to offend you.

speech.speaker: LOD.
speech.line: Truly, an obedient lady:
I do beseech your lordship call her back.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Mistress!

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: My lord?

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: What would you with her, sir?

speech.speaker: LOD.
speech.line: Who, I, my lord?

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Ay, you did wish that I would make her turn.
Sir, she can turn, and turn; and yet go on
And turn again; and she can weep, sir, weep;
And she’s obedient, as you say, obedient;
Very obedient—Proceed you in your tears.—
Concerning this, sir—O well-painted passion!—
I am commanded home.—Get you away;
I’ll send for you anon.—Sir, I obey the mandate,
And will return to Venice.—Hence, avaunt!
Cassio shall have my place. And, sir, tonight
I do entreat that we may sup together.
You are welcome, sir, to Cyprus.—Goats and monkeys!

speech.speaker: LOD.
speech.line: Is this the noble Moor whom our full Senate
Call all in all sufficient? Is this the nature
Whom passion could not shake? Whose solid virtue
The shot of accident nor dart of chance
Could neither graze nor pierce?

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: He is much chang’d.

speech.speaker: LOD.
speech.line: Are his wits safe? Is he not light of brain?

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: He’s that he is; I may not breathe my censure
What he might be. If what he might he is not,
I would to heaven he were!

speech.speaker: LOD.
speech.line: What? Strike his wife?

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Faith, that was not so well; yet would I knew
That stroke would prove the worst!

speech.speaker: LOD.
speech.line: Is it his use?
Or did the letters work upon his blood,
And new-create this fault?

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Alas, alas!
It is not honesty in me to speak
What I have seen and known. You shall observe him,
And his own courses will denote him so
That I may save my speech. Do but go after,
And mark how he continues.

speech.speaker: LOD.
speech.line: I am sorry that I am deceiv’d in him.

scene.scenelocation: Cyprus. A room in the castle.
scene.scenedescription: Othello questions Emilia, who swears that there is nothing between Desdemona and Cassio, but Othello refuses to believe her. He has Desdemona come in, and interrogates her, though Desdemona cannot see what it is he suspects her of. In the end he accuses her bluntly, and she protests her innocence with great dignity. He insults her callously, sneers at Emilia and leaves. Grieving, Desdemona asks Emilia to put her wedding sheets on the bed that night, and to call Iago to her. Iago comes in, feigning concern, and tries to console Desdemona while Emilia rails against whatever villain convinced Othello his wife was false. Iago tells Desdemona that it is only the cares of state that have disturbed Othello, and that things will get better. Desdemona and Emilia leave for the dinner for the Venetians. Roderigo comes to find Iago, reproaching him for not advancing his suit to Desdemona; he threatens to speak to Desdemona himself. This Iago cannot permit, for Roderigo has sent rich jewels to Desdemona that he, Iago, has taken for himself.
