Iago tells Roderigo that Cassio is to replace Othello on Cyprus, and that Othello is being sent farther away yet, and that therefore the only way to make sure Othello and Desdemona stay would be to kill Cassio so that he is not capable of taking on his new role. He offers to show Roderigo where the best place to lie in wait for Cassio would be; Roderigo needs more convincing, however.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: You have seen nothing then?

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: Nor ever heard—nor ever did suspect.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Yes, you have seen Cassio and she together.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: But then I saw no harm, and then I heard
Each syllable that breath made up between them.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: What? Did they never whisper?

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: Never, my lord.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Nor send you out o’ th’ way?

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: Never.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: To fetch her fan, her gloves, her mask, nor nothing?

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: Never, my lord.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: That’s strange.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: I durst, my lord, to wager she is honest;
Lay down my soul at stake. If you think other,
Remove your thought; it doth abuse your bosom.
If any wretch have put this in your head,
Let heaven requite it with the serpent’s curse!
For if she be not honest, chaste, and true,
There’s no man happy; the purest of their wives
Is foul as slander.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Bid her come hither; go.
She says enough; yet she’s a simple bawd
That cannot say as much. This is a subtile whore,
A closet lock and key of villainous secrets;
And yet she’ll kneel and pray; I have seen her do’t.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: My lord, what is your will?

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Pray you, chuck, come hither.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: What is your pleasure?

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Let me see your eyes;
Look in my face.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: What horrible fancy’s this?

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Some of your function, mistress;
Leave procreants alone, and shut the door;
Cough, or cry “hem,” if anybody come.
Your mystery, your mystery; nay, dispatch.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: Upon my knee, what doth your speech import?
I understand a fury in your words,
But not the words.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Why? What art thou?

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: Your wife, my lord; your true
And loyal wife.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Come swear it, damn thyself,
Lest being like one of heaven, the devils themselves
Should fear to seize thee; therefore be double damn’d:
Swear thou art honest.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: Heaven doth truly know it.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Heaven truly knows that thou art false as hell.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: To whom, my lord? With whom? How am I false?

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Ah, Desdemon! Away, away, away!

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: Alas the heavy day! Why do you weep?
Am I the motive of these tears, my lord?
If haply you my father do suspect
An instrument of this your calling back,
Lay not your blame on me. If you have lost him,
Why, I have lost him too.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Had it pleas’d heaven
To try me with affliction, had they rain’d
All kind of sores and shames on my bare head,
Steep’d me in poverty to the very lips,
Given to captivity me and my utmost hopes,
I should have found in some place of my soul
A drop of patience; but, alas, to make me
The fixed figure for the time of scorn
To point his slow unmoving finger at!
Yet could I bear that too, well, very well;
But there, where I have garner’d up my heart,
Where either I must live or bear no life;
The fountain from the which my current runs
Or else dries up: to be discarded thence!
Or keep it as a cestern for foul toads
To knot and gender in! Turn thy complexion there,
Patience, thou young and rose-lipp’d cherubin—
Ay, here look grim as hell!

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: I hope my noble lord esteems me honest.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: O ay, as summer flies are in the shambles,
That quicken even with blowing. O thou weed!
Who art so lovely fair and smell’st so sweet
That the sense aches at thee, would thou hadst never been born!

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: Alas, what ignorant sin have I committed?

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Was this fair paper, this most goodly book,
Made to write “whore” upon? What committed?
Committed? O thou public commoner,
I should make very forges of my cheeks,
That would to cinders burn up modesty,
Did I but speak thy deeds. What committed?
Heaven stops the nose at it, and the moon winks;
The bawdy wind, that kisses all it meets,
Is hush’d within the hollow mine of earth
And will not hear’t. What committed?
Impudent strumpet!

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: By heaven, you do me wrong.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Are not you a strumpet?

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: No, as I am a Christian.
If to preserve this vessel for my lord
From any other foul unlawful touch
Be not to be a strumpet, I am none.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: What, not a whore?

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: No, as I shall be sav’d.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Is’t possible?

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: O, heaven forgive us!

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: I cry you mercy then.
I took you for that cunning whore of Venice
That married with Othello.—
You, mistress,
That have the office opposite to Saint Peter,
And keeps the gate of hell! You, you! Ay, you!
We have done our course; there’s money for your pains.
I pray you turn the key and keep our counsel.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: Alas, what does this gentleman conceive?
How do you, madam? How do you, my good lady?

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: Faith, half asleep.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: Good madam, what’s the matter with my lord?

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: With who?

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: Why, with my lord, madam.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: Who is thy lord?

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: He that is yours, sweet lady.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: I have none. Do not talk to me, Emilia;
I cannot weep, nor answers have I none
But what should go by water. Prithee tonight
Lay on my bed my wedding-sheets—remember;
And call thy husband hither.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: Here’s a change indeed!

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: ’Tis meet I should be us’d so, very meet.
How have I been behav’d, that he might stick
The small’st opinion on my least misuse?

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: What is your pleasure, madam? How is’t with you?

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: I cannot tell. Those that do teach young babes
Do it with gentle means and easy tasks.
He might have chid me so; for in good faith
I am a child to chiding.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: What is the matter, lady?

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: Alas, Iago, my lord hath so bewhor’d her,
Thrown such despite and heavy terms upon her,
That true hearts cannot bear it.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: Am I that name, Iago?

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: What name, fair lady?

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: Such as she said my lord did say I was.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: He call’d her whore. A beggar in his drink
Could not have laid such terms upon his callet.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Why did he so?

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: I do not know; I am sure I am none such.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Do not weep, do not weep. Alas the day!

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: Hath she forsook so many noble matches?
Her father? And her country? And her friends?
To be call’d whore? Would it not make one weep?

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: It is my wretched fortune.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Beshrew him for’t!
How comes this trick upon him?

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: Nay, heaven doth know.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: I will be hang’d if some eternal villain,
Some busy and insinuating rogue,
Some cogging, cozening slave, to get some office,
Have not devis’d this slander. I will be hang’d else.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Fie, there is no such man; it is impossible.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: If any such there be, heaven pardon him!

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: A halter pardon him! And hell gnaw his bones!
Why should he call her whore? Who keeps her company?
What place? What time? What form? What likelihood?
The Moor’s abus’d by some most villainous knave,
Some base notorious knave, some scurvy fellow.
O heaven, that such companions thou’dst unfold,
And put in every honest hand a whip
To lash the rascals naked through the world
Even from the east to th’ west!

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Speak within door.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: O fie upon them! Some such squire he was
That turn’d your wit the seamy side without,
And made you to suspect me with the Moor.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: You are a fool; go to.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: Alas, Iago,
What shall I do to win my lord again?
Good friend, go to him; for by this light of heaven,
I know not how I lost him. Here I kneel:
If e’er my will did trespass ’gainst his love,
Either in discourse of thought or actual deed,
Or that mine eyes, mine ears, or any sense
Delighted them in any other form;
Or that I do not yet, and ever did,
And ever will (though he do shake me off
To beggarly divorcement) love him dearly,
Comfort forswear me! Unkindness may do much,
And his unkindness may defeat my life,
But never taint my love. I cannot say “whore.”
It does abhor me now I speak the word;
To do the act that might the addition earn,
Not the world’s mass of vanity could make me.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: I pray you be content; ’tis but his humor.
The business of the state does him offense,
And he does chide with you.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: If ’twere no other—

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: It is but so, I warrant.
Hark how these instruments summon to supper!
The messengers of Venice stays the meat.
Go in, and weep not; all things shall be well.
How now, Roderigo?

speech.speaker: ROD.
speech.line: I do not find that thou deal’st justly with me.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: What in the contrary?

speech.speaker: ROD.
speech.line: Every day thou daff’st me with some device, Iago, and rather, as it seems to me now, keep’st from me all conveniency than suppliest me with the least advantage of hope. I will indeed no longer endure it; nor am I yet persuaded to put up in peace what already I have foolishly suff’red.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Will you hear me, Roderigo?

speech.speaker: ROD.
speech.line: Faith, I have heard too much; for your words and performances are no kin together.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: You charge me most unjustly.

speech.speaker: ROD.
speech.line: With nought but truth. I have wasted myself out of my means. The jewels you have had from me to deliver Desdemona would half have corrupted a votarist. You have told me she hath receiv’d them and return’d me expectations and comforts of sudden respect and acquaintance, but I find none.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Well, go to; very well.

speech.speaker: ROD.
speech.line: Very well! Go to! I cannot go to, man, nor ’tis not very well. By this hand, I think it is scurvy, and begin to find myself fopp’d in it.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Very well.

speech.speaker: ROD.
speech.line: I tell you ’tis not very well. I will make myself known to Desdemona. If she will return me my jewels, I will give over my suit and repent my unlawful solicitation; if not, assure yourself I will seek satisfaction of you.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: You have said now.

speech.speaker: ROD.
speech.line: Ay; and said nothing but what I protest intendment of doing.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Why, now I see there’s mettle in thee, and even from this instant do build on thee a better opinion than ever before. Give me thy hand, Roderigo. Thou hast taken against me a most just exception; but yet I protest I have dealt most directly in thy affair.

speech.speaker: ROD.
speech.line: It hath not appear’d.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: I grant indeed it hath not appear’d; and your suspicion is not without wit and judgment. But, Roderigo, if thou hast that in thee indeed, which I have greater reason to believe now than ever (I mean purpose, courage, and valor), this night show it. If thou the next night following enjoy not Desdemona, take me from this world with treachery and devise engines for my life.

speech.speaker: ROD.
speech.line: Well; what is it? Is it within reason and compass?

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Sir, there is especial commission come from Venice to depute Cassio in Othello’s place.

speech.speaker: ROD.
speech.line: Is that true? Why then Othello and Desdemona return again to Venice.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: O no; he goes into Mauritania and taketh away with him the fair Desdemona, unless his abode be ling’red here by some accident; wherein none can be so determinate as the removing of Cassio.

speech.speaker: ROD.
speech.line: How do you mean, removing him?

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Why, by making him uncapable of Othello’s place: knocking out his brains.

speech.speaker: ROD.
speech.line: And that you would have me to do?

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Ay; if you dare do yourself a profit and a right. He sups tonight with a harlotry, and thither will I go to him—he knows not yet of his honorable fortune. If you will watch his going thence (which I will fashion to fall out between twelve and one), you may take him at your pleasure. I will be near to second your attempt, and he shall fall between us. Come, stand not amaz’d at it, but go along with me; I will show you such a necessity in his death that you shall think yourself bound to put it on him. It is now high supper-time, and the night grows to waste. About it.

speech.speaker: ROD.
speech.line: I will hear further reason for this.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: And you shall be satisfied.

scene.scenelocation: Cyprus. Another room in the castle.
scene.scenedescription: After dinner, Othello leads Lodovico and his attendants to their lodgings, ordering Desdemona to go to bed and dismiss Emilia. Emilia is concerned. Desdemona remembers a maid in her parents’ house who died of love, and sings a sad song that the maid had. She innocently asks Emilia if there actually are women who cheat on their husbands, and Emilia assures her that there are; when Desdemona says she would never do such a thing, Emilia replies that she might if the stakes were high enough. Emilia argues that the men are to blame if women do commit adultery, since the men do so themselves. Desdemona is shocked.
scene.stagedir: Enter Othello, Lodovico, Desdemona, Emilia, and Attendants.

speech.speaker: LOD.
speech.line: I do beseech you, sir, trouble yourself no further.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: O, pardon me; ’twill do me good to walk.

speech.speaker: LOD.
speech.line: Madam, good night; I humbly thank your ladyship.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: Your honor is most welcome.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Will you walk, sir?
O, Desdemona!

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: My lord?

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Get you to bed on th’ instant, I will be return’d forthwith. Dismiss your attendant there. Look’t be done.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: I will, my lord.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: How goes it now? He looks gentler than he did.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: He says he will return incontinent,
And hath commanded me to go to bed,
And bid me to dismiss you.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: Dismiss me?

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: It was his bidding; therefore, good Emilia,
Give me my nightly wearing, and adieu.
We must not now displease him.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: I would you had never seen him!

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: So would not I. My love doth so approve him,
That even his stubbornness, his checks, his frowns—
Prithee unpin me—have grace and favor in them.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: I have laid those sheets you bade me on the bed.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: All’s one. Good faith, how foolish are our minds!
If I do die before thee, prithee shroud me
In one of these same sheets.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: Come, come; you talk.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: My mother had a maid call’d Barbary;
She was in love, and he she lov’d prov’d mad,
And did forsake her. She had a song of “Willow,”
An old thing ’twas, but it express’d her fortune,
And she died singing it. That song tonight
Will not go from my mind; I have much to do
But to go hang my head all at one side
And sing it like poor Barbary. Prithee dispatch.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: Shall I go fetch your night-gown?

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: No, unpin me here.
This Lodovico is a proper man.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: A very handsome man.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: He speaks well.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: I know a lady in Venice would have walk’d barefoot to Palestine for a touch of his nether lip.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: “The poor soul sat sighing by a sycamore tree,
Sing all a green willow;
Her hand on her bosom, her head on her knee,
Sing willow, willow, willow.
The fresh streams ran by her, and murmur’d her moans,
Sing willow, willow, willow;
Her salt tears fell from her, and soft’ned the stones,
Sing willow”—
Lay by these—
“— willow, willow”—
Prithee hie thee; he’ll come anon—
“Sing all a green willow must be my garland.
Let nobody blame him, his scorn I approve”—
Nay, that’s not next. Hark, who is’t that knocks?

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: It’s the wind.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: “I call’d my love false love; but what said he then?
Sing willow, willow, willow;
If I court more women, You’ll couch with more men.”—
So get thee gone, good night. Mine eyes do itch;
Doth that bode weeping?

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: ’Tis neither here nor there.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: I have heard it said so. O, these men, these men!
Dost thou in conscience think—tell me, Emilia—
That there be women do abuse their husbands
In such gross kind?

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: There be some such, no question.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: Wouldst thou do such a deed for all the world?

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: Why, would not you?

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: No, by this heavenly light!

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: Nor I neither by this heavenly light;
I might do’t as well i’ th’ dark.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: Wouldst thou do such a deed for all the world?

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: The world’s a huge thing; it is a great price
For a small vice.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: Good troth, I think thou wouldst not.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: By my troth, I think I should, and undo’t when I had done’t. Marry, I would not do such a thing for a joint-ring, nor for measures of lawn, nor for gowns, petticoats, nor caps, nor any petty exhibition; but, for all the whole world—’ud’s pity, who would not make her husband a cuckold to make him a monarch? I should venture purgatory for’t.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: Beshrew me, if I would do such a wrong
For the whole world.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: Why, the wrong is but a wrong i’ th’ world; and having the world for your labor, ’tis a wrong in your own world, and you might quickly make it right.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: I do not think there is any such woman.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: Yes, a dozen; and as many to th’ vantage as would store the world they play’d for.
But I do think it is their husbands’ faults
If wives do fall. Say that they slack their duties,
And pour our treasures into foreign laps;
Or else break out in peevish jealousies,
Throwing restraint upon us; or say they strike us,
Or scant our former having in despite:
Why, we have galls; and though we have some grace,
Yet have we some revenge. Let husbands know
Their wives have sense like them; they see, and smell,
And have their palates both for sweet and sour,
As husbands have. What is it that they do
When they change us for others? Is it sport?
I think it is. And doth affection breed it?
I think it doth. Is’t frailty that thus errs?
It is so too. And have not we affections,
Desires for sport, and frailty, as men have?
Then let them use us well; else let them know,
The ills we do, their ills instruct us so.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: Good night, good night. God me such uses send,
Not to pick bad from bad, but by bad mend.

scene.scenepersonae: (Iago, Roderigo, Cassio, Othello, Lodovico, Gratiano, Bianca, Emilia)
scene.scenedescription: Iago places Roderigo at the right spot to kill Cassio; which one of the two dies does not much matter to Iago, who needs to be rid of both of them. When Cassio appears, Roderigo misses him; Cassio fights back and wounds Roderigo, while Iago stabs Cassio in the leg from behind. Othello hears Cassio’s cries and is delighted, thinking he is dead. Lodovico and Gratiano arrive at the scene, wondering what has happened; Iago appears as if just woken, and in the dark stabs Roderigo to death. The confusion is great, and when Bianca arrives, Iago manages to pin the blame on her and orders her arrested on suspicion of having arranged the crime. He binds up Cassio’s wounds and sends him to a doctor. Emilia arrives to find out what all the noise is about, and Iago sends her to tell Othello and Desdemona what has happened. He realizes that things may or may not go well for him tonight.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Here, stand behind this bulk, straight will he come.
Wear thy good rapier bare, and put it home.
Quick, quick, fear nothing; I’ll be at thy elbow.
It makes us, or it mars us, think on that,
And fix most firm thy resolution.

speech.speaker: ROD.
speech.line: Be near at hand, I may miscarry in’t.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Here, at thy hand; be bold, and take thy stand.

speech.speaker: ROD.
speech.line: I have no great devotion to the deed,
And yet he hath given me satisfying reasons.
’Tis but a man gone. Forth my sword; he dies.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: I have rubb’d this young quat almost to the sense,
And he grows angry. Now, whether he kill Cassio,
Or Cassio him, or each do kill the other,
Every way makes my gain. Live Roderigo,
He calls me to a restitution large
Of gold and jewels that I bobb’d from him
As gifts to Desdemona;
It must not be. If Cassio do remain,
He hath a daily beauty in his life
That makes me ugly; and besides, the Moor
May unfold me to him; there stand I in much peril.
No, he must die. Be’t so. I hear him coming.

speech.speaker: ROD.
speech.line: I know his gait, ’tis he.—Villain, thou diest!

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: That thrust had been mine enemy indeed,
But that my coat is better than thou know’st.
I will make proof of thine.

speech.speaker: ROD.
speech.line: O, I am slain.

scene.stagedir: Iago from behind wounds Cassio in the leg, and exit.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: I am maim’d forever. Help ho! Murder, murder!

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: The voice of Cassio! Iago keeps his word.

speech.speaker: ROD.
speech.line: O, villain that I am!

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: It is even so.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: O, help ho! Light! A surgeon!

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: ’Tis he!—O brave Iago, honest and just,
That hast such noble sense of thy friend’s wrong!
Thou teachest me. Minion, your dear lies dead,
And your unblest fate hies. Strumpet, I come.
Forth of my heart those charms, thine eyes, are blotted;
Thy bed, lust-stain’d, shall with lust’s blood be spotted.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: What ho! No watch? No passage? Murder, murder!

speech.speaker: GRA.
speech.line: ’Tis some mischance, the voice is very direful.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: O, help!

speech.speaker: LOD.
speech.line: Hark!

speech.speaker: ROD.
speech.line: O wretched villin!

speech.speaker: LOD.
speech.line: Two or three groan. ’Tis heavy night;
These may be counterfeits; let’s think’t unsafe
To come in to the cry without more help.

speech.speaker: ROD.
speech.line: Nobody come? Then shall I bleed to death.

speech.speaker: LOD.
speech.line: Hark!

speech.speaker: GRA.
speech.line: Here’s one comes in his shirt, with light and weapons.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Who’s there? Whose noise is this that cries on murder?

speech.speaker: LOD.
speech.line: We do not know.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Did not you hear a cry?

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: Here, here! For heaven sake help me!

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: What’s the matter?

speech.speaker: GRA.
speech.line: This is Othello’s ancient, as I take it.

speech.speaker: LOD.
speech.line: The same indeed, a very valiant fellow.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: What are you here that cry so grievously?

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: Iago? O, I am spoil’d, undone by villains!
Give me some help.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: O me, lieutenant! What villains have done this?

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: I think that one of them is hereabout,
And cannot make away.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: O treacherous villains!
What are you there?
Come in, and give some help.

speech.speaker: ROD.
speech.line: O, help me there!

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: That’s one of them.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: O murd’rous slave! O villain!

speech.speaker: ROD.
speech.line: O damn’d Iago! O inhuman dog!

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Kill men i’ th’ dark?—Where be these bloody thieves?—
How silent is this town!—Ho, murder, murder!—
What may you be? Are you of good or evil?

speech.speaker: LOD.
speech.line: As you shall prove us, praise us.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Signior Lodovico?

speech.speaker: LOD.
speech.line: He, sir.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: I cry you mercy. Here’s Cassio hurt by villains.

speech.speaker: GRA.
speech.line: Cassio?

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: How is’t, brother?

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: My leg is cut in two.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Marry, heaven forbid!
Light, gentlemen! I’ll bind it with my shirt.

speech.speaker: BIAN.
speech.line: What is the matter ho? Who is’t that cried?

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Who is’t that cried?

speech.speaker: BIAN.
speech.line: O my dear Cassio, my sweet Cassio!
O Cassio, Cassio, Cassio!

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: O notable strumpet! Cassio, may you suspect
Who they should be that have thus mangled you?

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: No.

speech.speaker: GRA.
speech.line: I am sorry to find you thus; I have been to seek you.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Lend me a garter. So.—O for a chair
To bear him easily hence!

speech.speaker: BIAN.
speech.line: Alas, he faints! O Cassio, Cassio, Cassio!

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Gentlemen all, I do suspect this trash
To be a party in this injury.—
Patience awhile, good Cassio.—Come, come;
Lend me a light. Know we this face or no?
Alas, my friend and my dear countryman
Roderigo! No—yes, sure—O heaven, Roderigo!

speech.speaker: GRA.
speech.line: What, of Venice?

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Even he, sir; did you know him?

speech.speaker: GRA.
speech.line: Know him? Ay.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Signior Gratiano? I cry your gentle pardon;
These bloody accidents must excuse my manners
That so neglected you.

speech.speaker: GRA.
speech.line: I am glad to see you.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: How do you, Cassio? O, a chair, a chair!

speech.speaker: GRA.
speech.line: Roderigo!

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: He, he,’tis he.
O, that’s well said: the chair.
Some good man bear him carefully from hence,
I’ll fetch the general’s surgeon.
For you, mistress,
Save you your labor.—He that lies slain here, Cassio,
Was my dear friend. What malice was between you?

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: None in the world; nor do I know the man.

speech.speaker: IAGO
speech.line: What? Look you pale?—O, bear him out o’ th’ air.
speech.stagedir: Cassio and Roderigo are borne off.
speech.line: Stay you, good gentlemen.—Look you pale, mistress?—
Do you perceive the gastness of her eye?—
Nay, an’ you stare, we shall hear more anon.—
Behold her well; I pray you look upon her.
Do you see, gentlemen? Nay, guiltiness will speak,
Though tongues were out of use.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: Alas, what is the matter? What is the matter, husband?

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Cassio hath here been set on in the dark
By Roderigo and fellows that are scap’d.
He’s almost slain, and Roderigo quite dead.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: Alas, good gentleman! Alas, good Cassio!

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: This is the fruits of whoring. Prithee, Emilia,
Go know of Cassio where he supp’d tonight.
What, do you shake at that?

speech.speaker: BIAN.
speech.line: He supp’d at my house, but I therefore shake not.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: O, did he so? I charge you go with me.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: O fie upon thee, strumpet!

speech.speaker: BIAN.
speech.line: I am no strumpet, but of life as honest
As you that thus abuse me.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: As I? Fough, fie upon thee!

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Kind gentlemen, let’s go see poor Cassio dress’d.
Come, mistress, you must tell ’s another tale.
Emilia, run you to the citadel,
And tell my lord and lady what hath happ’d.—
Will you go on afore?
This is the night
That either makes me, or foredoes me quite.

scene.scenepersonae: (Othello, Desdemona, Emilia, Montano, Gratiano, Iago, Lodovico, Cassio)
scene.scenedescription: Othello enters the bedchamber where Desdemona lies sleeping, considering how it is necessary that she die. He kisses her, almost convincing himself not to kill her, but he steels himself to the task. His kisses wake her. He orders her to pray, informing her that she is about to die. She begs for mercy, denying all of his accusations, but he refuses to listen, and smothers her. Emilia knocks at the door, calling for Othello. Thinking that she has come to tell him of Cassio’s death, he is uncertain what to do, reluctant to let her in lest she try to speak to Desdemona. In the end he lets her in, and she blurts out her news. At that moment Desdemona calls out, and Emilia runs to her and tries to unsuccessfully to revive her. Desdemona insists that nobody did anything to her and dies. Othello calls her a liar and tells Emilia that he killed her. He tells Emilia why, and she is horrified and does not want to believe him when he says that Iago was the one who accused Desdemona. Despite Othello’s threats, she opens the door and yells out for help. Montano, Gratiano and Iago enter, and Emilia begs her husband to deny what Othello has said, but he cannot. He orders her to be quiet and go home, but she refuses, and when Othello brings out the proof of the handkerchief, she tells him that it was she who stole the handkerchief and gave it to Iago. Iago denies it, but Othello sees the truth and rushes at him; Iago stabs Emilia and runs out. The others chase after him, leaving Othello and Emilia with Desdemona’s body. He finds a spare sword in the room and arms himself with it, but does nothing as the extent of what he has done crushes him. Lodovico enters with the injured Cassio and the captured Iago. The story is unraveled, but Iago refuses to give any explanation for what he has done. Lodovico informs Othello that he must come with them to Venice, but Othello begs him to wait a moment; he explains what he has done in the state’s service, and thinking of one last example, he stabs himself. Dying, he drags himself to the bed to kiss Desdemona one last time as he dies. Lodovico plans to return to Venice, begging Cassio to make Iago suffer before he dies.
scene.stagedir: Enter Othello with a light and Desdemona in her bed asleep.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: It is the cause, it is the cause, my soul;
Let me not name it to you, you chaste stars,
It is the cause. Yet I’ll not shed her blood,
Nor scar that whiter skin of hers than snow,
And smooth as monumental alabaster.
Yet she must die, else she’ll betray more men.
Put out the light, and then put out the light:
If I quench thee, thou flaming minister,
I can again thy former light restore,
Should I repent me; but once put out thy light,
Thou cunning’st pattern of excelling nature,
I know not where is that Promethean heat
That can thy light relume. When I have pluck’d thy rose,
I cannot give it vital growth again,
It needs must wither. I’ll smell thee on the tree.
O balmy breath, that dost almost persuade
Justice to break her sword! One more, one more.
Be thus when thou art dead, and I will kill thee
And love thee after. One more, and that’s the last.
So sweet was ne’er so fatal. I must weep,
But they are cruel tears. This sorrow’s heavenly,
It strikes where it doth love. She wakes.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: Who’s there? Othello?

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Ay, Desdemona.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: Will you come to bed, my lord?

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Have you pray’d tonight, Desdemon?

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: Ay, my lord.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: If you bethink yourself of any crime
Unreconcil’d as yet to heaven and grace,
Solicit for it straight.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: Alack, my lord, what may you mean by that?

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Well, do it, and be brief, I will walk by.
I would not kill thy unprepared spirit,
No, heaven forefend! I would not kill thy soul.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: Talk you of killing?

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Ay, I do.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: Then heaven
Have mercy on me!

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Amen, with all my heart!

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: If you say so, I hope you will not kill me.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Humh!

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: And yet I fear you; for you’re fatal then
When your eyes roll so. Why I should fear I know not,
Since guiltiness I know not; but yet I feel I fear.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Think on thy sins.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: They are loves I bear to you.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Ay, and for that thou di’st.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: That death’s unnatural that kills for loving.
Alas, why gnaw you so your nether lip?
Some bloody passion shakes your very frame.
These are portents; but yet I hope, I hope,
They do not point on me.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Peace, and be still!

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: I will so. What’s the matter?

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: That handkerchief which I so lov’d, and gave thee,
Thou gav’st to Cassio.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: No, by my life and soul!
Send for the man, and ask him.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Sweet soul, take heed,
Take heed of perjury, thou art on thy death-bed.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: Ay, but not yet to die.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Yes, presently:
Therefore confess thee freely of thy sin;
For to deny each article with oath
Cannot remove nor choke the strong conception
That I do groan withal. Thou art to die.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: Then Lord have mercy on me!

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: I say, amen.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: And have you mercy too! I never did
Offend you in my life; never lov’d Cassio
But with such general warranty of heaven
As I might love. I never gave him token.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: By heaven, I saw my handkerchief in ’s hand.
O perjur’d woman, thou dost stone my heart,
And mak’st me call what I intend to do
A murder, which I thought a sacrifice.
I saw the handkerchief.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: He found it then;
I never gave it him. Send for him hither;
Let him confess a truth.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: He hath confess’d.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: What, my lord?

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: That he hath us’d thee.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: How? Unlawfully?

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Ay.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: He will not say so.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: No—his mouth is stopp’d;
Honest Iago hath ta’en order for’t.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: O, my fear interprets. What, is he dead?

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Had all his hairs been lives, my great revenge
Had stomach for them all.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: Alas, he is betray’d and I undone!

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Out, strumpet! Weep’st thou for him to my face?

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: O, banish me, my lord, but kill me not!

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Down, strumpet!d

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: Kill me tomorrow, let me live tonight!

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Nay, an’ you strive—

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: But half an hour!

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Being done, there is no pause.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: But while I say one prayer!

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: It is too late.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: O Lord, Lord, Lord!

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: My lord, my lord!
What ho! My lord, my lord!

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: What noise is this? Not dead? Not yet quite dead?
I that am cruel am yet merciful,
I would not have thee linger in thy pain.
So, so.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: What ho! My lord, my lord!

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Who’s there?

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: O, good my lord, I would speak a word with you!

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Yes.—’Tis Emilia.—By and by.—She’s dead.
’Tis like she comes to speak of Cassio’s death;
The noise was high. Hah, no more moving?
Still as the grave. Shall she come in? Were’t good?
I think she stirs again. No. What’s best to do?
If she come in, she’ll sure speak to my wife.
My wife, my wife! What wife? I have no wife.
O insupportable! O heavy hour!
Methinks it should be now a huge eclipse
Of sun and moon, and that th’ affrighted globe
Did yawn at alteration.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: I do beseech you
That I may speak with you. O, good my lord!

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: I had forgot thee. O, come in, Emilia.—
Soft, by and by, let me the curtains draw.—
Where art thou?
What’s the matter with thee now?

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: O, my good lord, yonder’s foul murders done!

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: What? Now?

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: But now, my lord.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: It is the very error of the moon,
She comes more nearer earth than she was wont,
And makes men mad.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: Cassio, my lord, hath kill’d a young Venetian
Call’d Roderigo.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Roderigo kill’d?
And Cassio kill’d?

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: No, Cassio is not kill’d.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Not Cassio kill’d? Then murder’s out of tune,
And sweet revenge grows harsh.

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: O, falsely, falsely murder’d!

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: O Lord, what cry is that?

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: That? What?

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: Out, and alas, that was my lady’s voice.
Help, help, ho, help! O lady, speak again!
Sweet Desdemona, O sweet mistress, speak!

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: A guiltless death I die.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: O, who hath done this deed?

speech.speaker: DES.
speech.line: Nobody; I myself. Farewell!
Commend me to my kind lord. O, farewell!

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Why, how should she be murd’red?

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: Alas! Who knows?

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: You heard her say herself, it was not I.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: She said so; I must needs report the truth.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: She’s like a liar gone to burning hell:
’Twas I that kill’d her.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: O, the more angel she,
And you the blacker devil!

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: She turn’d to folly, and she was a whore.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: Thou dost belie her, and thou art a devil.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: She was false as water.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: Thou art rash as fire to say
That she was false. O, she was heavenly true!

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Cassio did top her; ask thy husband else.
O, I were damn’d beneath all depth in hell
But that I did proceed upon just grounds
To this extremity. Thy husband knew it all.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: My husband?

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Thy husband.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: That she was false to wedlock?

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Ay, with Cassio. Nay, had she been true,
If heaven would make me such another world
Of one entire and perfect chrysolite,
I’ld not have sold her for it.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: My husband?

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Ay, ’twas he that told me on her first.
An honest man he is, and hates the slime
That sticks on filthy deeds.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: My husband?

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: What needs this iterance, woman? I say thy husband.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: O mistress, villainy hath made mocks with love!
My husband say she was false?

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: He, woman:
I say thy husband; dost understand the word?
My friend, thy husband, honest, honest Iago.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: If he say so, may his pernicious soul
Rot half a grain a day! He lies to th’ heart.
She was too fond of her most filthy bargain.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Hah?

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: Do thy worst!
This deed of thine is no more worthy heaven
Than thou wast worthy her.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Peace, you were best.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: Thou hast not half that pow’r to do me harm
As I have to be hurt. O gull, O dolt,
As ignorant as dirt! Thou hast done a deed—
I care not for thy sword, I’ll make thee known,
Though I lost twenty lives. Help, help, ho, help!
The Moor hath kill’d my mistress! Murder, murder!

scene.stagedir: Enter Montano, Gratiano, and Iago, with others.

speech.speaker: MON.
speech.line: What is the matter? How now, general?

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: O, are you come, Iago? You have done well,
That men must lay their murders on your neck.

speech.speaker: GRA.
speech.line: What is the matter?

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: Disprove this villain, if thou be’st a man.
He says thou toldst him that his wife was false.
I know thou didst not; thou’rt not such a villain.
Speak, for my heart is full.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: I told him what I thought, and told no more
Than what he found himself was apt and true.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: But did you ever tell him she was false?

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: I did.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: You told a lie, an odious, damned lie;
Upon my soul, a lie, a wicked lie.
She false with Cassio? Did you say with Cassio?

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: With Cassio, mistress. Go to, charm your tongue.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: I will not charm my tongue; I am bound to speak.
My mistress here lies murdered in her bed—

speech.speaker: ALL.
speech.line: O heavens forefend!

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: And your reports have set the murder on.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Nay, stare not, masters, it is true indeed.

speech.speaker: GRA.
speech.line: ’Tis a strange truth.

speech.speaker: MON.
speech.line: O monstrous act!

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: Villainy, villainy, villainy!
I think upon’t, I think—I smell’t—O villainy!
I thought so then—I’ll kill myself for grief—
O villainy! Villainy!

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: What, are you mad? I charge you get you home.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: Good gentlemen, let me have leave to speak.
’Tis proper I obey him; but not now.
Perchance, Iago, I will ne’er go home.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: O, O, O!

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: Nay, lay thee down and roar;
For thou hast kill’d the sweetest innocent
That e’er did lift up eye.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: O, she was foul!
I scarce did know you, uncle; there lies your niece,
Whose breath, indeed, these hands have newly stopp’d.
I know this act shows horrible and grim.

speech.speaker: GRA.
speech.line: Poor Desdemon! I am glad thy father’s dead.
Thy match was mortal to him, and pure grief
Shore his old thread in twain. Did he live now,
This sight would make him do a desperate turn,
Yea, curse his better angel from his side,
And fall to reprobance.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: ’Tis pitiful; but yet Iago knows
That she with Cassio hath the act of shame
A thousand times committed. Cassio confess’d it,
And she did gratify his amorous works
With that recognizance and pledge of love
Which I first gave her. I saw it in his hand;
It was a handkerchief, an antique token
My father gave my mother.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: O God! O heavenly God!

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: ’Zounds, hold your peace.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: ’Twill out, ’twill out! I peace?
No, I will speak as liberal as the north:
Let heaven and men and devils, let them all,
All, all, cry shame against me, yet I’ll speak.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Be wise, and get you home.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: I will not.

speech.speaker: GRA.
speech.line: Fie,
Your sword upon a woman?

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: O thou dull Moor, that handkerchief thou speak’st of
I found by fortune, and did give my husband;
For often, with a solemn earnestness
(More than indeed belong’d to such a trifle),
He begg’d of me to steal’t.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Villainous whore!

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: She give it Cassio? No, alas, I found it,
And I did give’t my husband.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Filth, thou liest!

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: By heaven, I do not, I do not, gentlemen.
O murd’rous coxcomb, what should such a fool
Do with so good a wife?

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Are there no stones in heaven
But what serves for the thunder?—Precious villain!

scene.stagedir: The Moor runs at Iago; Montano disarms Othello; Iago kills his wife.

speech.speaker: GRA.
speech.line: The woman falls; sure he hath kill’d his wife.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: Ay, ay! O, lay me by my mistress’ side.

speech.speaker: GRA.
speech.line: He’s gone, but his wife’s kill’d.

speech.speaker: MON.
speech.line: ’Tis a notorious villain. Take you this weapon
Which I have here recover’d from the Moor.
Come guard the door without; let him not pass,
But kill him rather. I’ll after that same villain,
For ’tis a damned slave.

scene.stagedir: Exit with all but Othello and Emilia.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: I am not valiant neither,
But every puny whipster gets my sword.
But why should honor outlive honesty?
Let it go all.

speech.speaker: EMIL.
speech.line: What did thy song bode, lady?
Hark, canst thou hear me? I will play the swan,
And die in music.
Willow, willow, willow.
Moor, she was chaste; she lov’d thee, cruel Moor;
So come my soul to bliss, as I speak true;
So speaking as I think, alas, I die.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: I have another weapon in this chamber;
It was a sword of Spain, the ice-brook’s temper—
O, here it is. Uncle, I must come forth.

speech.speaker: GRA.
speech.line: If thou attempt it, it will cost thee dear:
Thou hast no weapon, and perforce must suffer.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Look in upon me then and speak with me,
Or naked as I am I will assault thee.

speech.speaker: GRA.
speech.line: What is the matter?

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Behold, I have a weapon;
A better never did itself sustain
Upon a soldier’s thigh. I have seen the day
That with this little arm, and this good sword,
I have made my way through more impediments
Than twenty times your stop. But (O vain boast!)
Who can control his fate? ’Tis not so now.
Be not afraid though you do see me weapon’d;
Here is my journey’s end, here is my butt
And very sea-mark of my utmost sail.
Do you go back dismay’d? ’Tis a lost fear;
Man but a rush against Othello’s breast,
And he retires. Where should Othello go?
Now—how dost thou look now? O ill-starr’d wench,
Pale as thy smock! When we shall meet at compt,
This look of thine will hurl my soul from heaven,
And fiends will snatch at it. Cold, cold, my girl?
Even like thy chastity. O cursed, cursed slave!
Whip me, ye devils,
From the possession of this heavenly sight!
Blow me about in winds! Roast me in sulphur!
Wash me in steep-down gulfs of liquid fire!
O Desdemon! Dead, Desdemon! Dead!
O, O!

scene.stagedir: Enter Lodovico, Cassio in a chair, Montano, and Iago guarded, with Officers.

speech.speaker: LOD.
speech.line: Where is this rash and most unfortunate man?

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: That’s he that was Othello; here I am.

speech.speaker: LOD.
speech.line: Where is that viper? Bring the villain forth.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: I look down towards his feet; but that’s a fable.
If that thou be’st a devil, I cannot kill thee.

speech.speaker: LOD.
speech.line: Wrench his sword from him.

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: I bleed, sir, but not kill’d.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: I am not sorry neither, I’ld have thee live;
For in my sense, ’tis happiness to die.

speech.speaker: LOD.
speech.line: O thou Othello, that was once so good,
Fall’n in the practice of a damned slave,
What shall be said to thee?

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Why, any thing:
An honorable murderer, if you will;
For nought I did in hate, but all in honor.

speech.speaker: LOD.
speech.line: This wretch hath part confess’d his villainy.
Did you and he consent in Cassio’s death?

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Ay.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: Dear general, I never gave you cause.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: I do believe it, and I ask your pardon.
Will you, I pray, demand that demi-devil
Why he hath thus ensnar’d my soul and body?

speech.speaker: IAGO.
speech.line: Demand me nothing; what you know, you know:
From this time forth I never will speak word.

speech.speaker: LOD.
speech.line: What? Not to pray?

speech.speaker: GRA.
speech.line: Torments will ope your lips.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Well, thou dost best.

speech.speaker: LOD.
speech.line: Sir, you shall understand what hath befall’n,
Which, as I think, you know not. Here is a letter
Found in the pocket of the slain Roderigo,
And here another. The one of them imports
The death of Cassio to be undertook
By Roderigo.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: O villain!

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: Most heathenish and most gross!

speech.speaker: LOD.
speech.line: Now here’s another discontented paper,
Found in his pocket too; and this it seems
Roderigo meant t’ have sent this damned villain;
But that, belike, Iago in the nick
Came in and satisfied him.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: O thou pernicious caitiff!—
How came you, Cassio, by that handkerchief
That was my wive’s?

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: I found it in my chamber:
And he himself confess’d it but even now,
That there he dropp’d it for a special purpose
Which wrought to his desire.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: O fool, fool, fool!

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: There is besides, in Roderigo’s letter,
How he upbraids Iago, that he made him
Brave me upon the watch, whereon it came
That I was cast; and even but now he spake
(After long seeming dead) Iago hurt him,
Iago set him on.

speech.speaker: LOD.
speech.line: You must forsake this room and go with us.
Your power and your command is taken off,
And Cassio rules in Cyprus. For this slave,
If there be any cunning cruelty
That can torment him much, and hold him long,
It shall be his. You shall close prisoner rest,
Till that the nature of your fault be known
To the Venetian state. Come, bring away.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: Soft you; a word or two before you go.
I have done the state some service, and they know’t—
No more of that. I pray you, in your letters,
When you shall these unlucky deeds relate,
Speak of me as I am; nothing extenuate,
Nor set down aught in malice. Then must you speak
Of one that lov’d not wisely but too well;
Of one not easily jealous, but being wrought,
Perplexed in the extreme; of one whose hand
(Like the base Indian) threw a pearl away
Richer than all his tribe; of one whose subdu’d eyes,
Albeit unused to the melting mood,
Drops tears as fast as the Arabian trees
Their medicinable gum. Set you down this;
And say besides, that in Aleppo once,
Where a malignant and a turban’d Turk
Beat a Venetian and traduc’d the state,
I took by th’ throat the circumcised dog,
And smote him—thus.

speech.speaker: LOD.
speech.line: O bloody period!

speech.speaker: GRA.
speech.line: All that is spoke is marr’d.

speech.speaker: OTH.
speech.line: I kiss’d thee ere I kill’d thee. No way but this,
Killing myself, to die upon a kiss.

scene.stagedir: Falls on the bed and dies.

speech.speaker: CAS.
speech.line: This did I fear, but thought he had no weapon;
For he was great of heart.

speech.speaker: LOD.
speech.line: O Spartan dog,
More fell than anguish, hunger, or the sea!
Look on the tragic loading of this bed;
This is thy work. The object poisons sight,
Let it be hid. Gratiano, keep the house,
And seize upon the fortunes of the Moor,
For they succeed on you. To you, Lord Governor,
Remains the censure of this hellish villain,
The time, the place, the torture, O, enforce it!
Myself will straight aboard, and to the state
This heavy act with heavy heart relate.
